characters: PERSONS DEPARTMENT, SACRAMENTO MISSING PERSONS DEPARTMENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On which appears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words slowly FADE OUT, taking us hard into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, pleasant house on a tree-lined street in Los Ang circa 1928. 210 North Avenue 23. Not far from Dodger Stad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Bakelite alarm clock hits 6:30 A.M. and RINGS. CHRISTIN COLLINS, thirties, attractive, rumpled, reaches INTO FRAM shut it off. She sits up, rubs tiredly at her face, and m OS, switching on a radio as she goes. Music fills the air

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws water on her face as the music continues. She looks at herself in the mirror as the light flickers over She hits the wall offhandedly, something she does every d The flickering stops. With a last look at the mirror, she smoothes back her hair and exits, switching off the light

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed now, she flicks on the overhead light. WALTER COL is nine years old, with light brown hair, though we don't much of it or him, he's entangled in the sheets. It's important that we don't see him too clearly in most of th following scenes, but without drawing attention to that a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter...time for school, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits on the edge of the bed, runs a hand through his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just ten more minutes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, champ. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE (Cont'd) You can sleep in all you want tomorrow, that's what Saturdays are for. Now hurry up or your breakfast will get cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cereal, it's supposed to be cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, kisses him on the forehead, and exits. He sit on the edge of the bed, wavers, then falls back into bed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A street-car (known then as the Big Red) rumbles down the street in the gray light of morning, passing Ford Model A and Hudsons and Nash four-door sedans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine sits on one of the benches, Walter's face burie her lap, still half-asleep. She nudges him as they come t an intersection by a grade school. It's early enough that only a few other kids have arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here, sweetie.   Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him a sack lunch and follows as he slouches tow the door. She watches from the curb as he heads toward th school. Some of the teachers lounging outside nod to her Walter approaches, so she knows they're aware that he's t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves, then hurriedly gets back on the street-car as rumbles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Located on Grand Avenue downtown, the huge switchboard ro is a maze of switching stations, tangles of wires and hea wooden headsets...a roar of buzzers, bells, circuits open and closing, and a hundred female operators speaking at o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supervisors on skates roll up and down the narrow lanes c by the banks of switching stations, going from one operat to another as needed. Christine is one of them. She turns at the SOUND of a bell struck twice, then rolls down the toward an OPERATOR frantically waving a pink sheet of pap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay Sandy, what's the prob--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mortified operator hands her the headset and stalks o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You deal with this one, I'm not going near it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine struggles on the headset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes, this is the supervisor, ma'am, what can I -- (checks board) Yes, I can see that you're on a party line, ma'am, what can I -- (beat) I know, it's unfortunate, but people sometimes do listen in on party lines. We hope to have private lines installed by -- (beat) Well, what's he doing when you're on the phone? (beat) Are you sure? Maybe there's a problem with the phone line. He could be asthmatic, or -- (beat) Oh. No, I...I've never heard of anything like that before either. Guess there's a first time for everything, right? No, I'm afraid there's nothing we can do about people abusing the equipment or... themselves. I'm sorry. I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reacts to the phone being hung up hard at the other e as the floor manager, BEN HARRIS, 30s, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Mr. Harris...fine...just someone having a problem with a... with the connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them to take the plug and shove it in and out a few times, that'll usually do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately that was part of the problem. If you'll excuse me....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She roller-skates off toward another operator waving anot pink sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine sits alone, eating a bag lunch and reading a th telephone company manual. Working hard to advance herself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a bell rings: time to return to work. Other employee gather up their belongings and start inside. As Christine closes the book, her bookmark falls out. As she picks it we see that it's a child's drawing: her and Walter (with indicating who is who) on a green hill, under an orange s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches the drawing and smiles as the bell rings agai She grabs her belongs and heads back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine waits outside the school as another bell rings, announcing the end of classes. Kids run outside, Walter a them. He folds in alongside as they start down the sidewa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how was school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. We learned about dinosaurs, and I got in a fight with Billy Mankowski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hit him back? (he nods) Good. Rule number one: Never start a fight, but always finish it. So why did he hit you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I hit him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...you hit him first? (he nods) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said my dad ran off because he didn't like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dad never even had a chance to meet you...so how could he not like you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did he leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine takes his hand, and they continue down the side

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the same day you were born, something else arrived. It came in the mail, in a box just slightly bigger than you. You know what was in that box? (he shakes head) Something called responsibility. Now, to some people, responsibility is fun, it's what you live your whole life for. Other people think it's the scariest thing in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he ran away because he was scared of what was in the box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's dumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and crouches down in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, I decided a long time ago that I would always tell you the truth, that I would treat you like a grown-up. I can't expect you to respect me unless I respect you. (beat) I've never lied to you. Your father leaving had nothing to do with you, and everything to do with what was in the responsibility box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinky-swear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinky-swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his pinky in hers, gives a tug.    He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First one to the corner store gets ice cream!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs and tears off. She runs after him, letting him stay ahead of her the whole way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is asleep on the floor, in front of the radio, whi is playing the closing moments of Amos and Andy. Christin enters and turns off the radio. He stirs, looks up at her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I miss Amos and Andy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so, sport.   Come on now, time for bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks him up and carries him up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we still going to the movies tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. I hear there's a new Charlie Chaplin playing down at Grauman's, and a new serial called The Mysterious Airman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Nobody does. That's what makes him so mysterious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   Am I too heavy for you to carry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for years yet, Walter.     Not for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she disappears upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just enough to bring us into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's getting ready for the day and is almost out of the when the phone rings. She hesitates, then picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? (beat) Oh, hello, Margaret. I'm fine, thanks. No, I was just -- (beat) You're kidding. When did she call in sick? (checks watch) What about Myrna? I know she could use the extra hours. Oh. No, it's just...I promised Walter I'd take him to the movies today. There has to be somebody else.... (beat) All right, I...guess we can do it tomorrow. I'll get there as soon as I can. But just until four, okay? See you in a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up. She doesn't like this, but there's no way o of it. She straightens and heads out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disappointed Walter sits on the couch as Christine puts things together quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a sandwich and milk in the icebox, and I've asked Mrs. Riley if her daughter can stop by in a couple of hours, just to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take care of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you can. She's coming by to check on the house, not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops in front of him, kneels down to eye height.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, we'll go to the movies. Then we'll ride the Big Red down to Santa Monica and walk on the pier. How's that? That okay? (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE (Cont'd) (he nods) Good. I'll be back before it gets dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid of the dark.     I'm not afraid of anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're not, honey. That's how I raised you. (kisses his head) Be good. See you in a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads out, the screen door clattering shut behind her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses the lawn and turns at the sidewalk, glancing as Walter looks out at her from the window. She waves. He waves back. With one last look, she continues off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the place was hectic before, now it's even worse: line buzzing, voices chattering, operators following Christine around with papers and question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got lines jammed from here to Ohio...he insists on talking to someone in charge...I've tried everything and the console's just dead...I need your signature here for a supply requisition....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine glances up at the clock, 4:39.    She's already But she does what's necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, get me the Omaha routing station, see if we can put the calls through their switchers...and let's get that console running....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurries off to take care of it all, the others follow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: START on a clock which reads 5:20, then TILT DOWN as Chri comes out of the switchboard room, pulling on a sweater, to leave...as the floor manager steps out of his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine...good, I was hoping to catch you. I've been following your work reports, and I just want you to know that I'm very impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances down the block. The street car is approaching but she doesn't want to piss off her boss by running off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I first suggested hiring female supervisors, my superiors weren't big on the idea. But you've held your own as well as any of our male supervisors, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Harris, but I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, please. Point is, we're looking for someone to take on a managerial position in our new Beverly Hills office. If you're interested I can --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, Mr. Harris, I really appreciate the vote of confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good...so maybe we could --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up to see the streetcar right at the stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but I really have to go. We'll talk on Monday. Good night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She races out to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: running after the streetcar as it closes its doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...wait...hold on, just a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the streetcar rumbles away before she can catch it. Frustrated, she glances at her watch and sighs resignedly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine sits on the front bench, watching as the shadow lengthen, then pulls the bell. The car rumbles to a stop she steps out onto the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She passes a grocery store, where a clock reads 6:15, and continues past other houses on the pleasant, green street We HEAR parents telling their kids to come in for dinner, radios playing music or radio dramas. Peaceful, charming. Christine smiles, turns the corner, looks to her house --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and it's dark, closed up. No lights on inside, no musi or dramas on the radio. Dead silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine pauses, then picks up her pace. No need to pani he could be upstairs asleep, could be in the back of the where the lights wouldn't show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the front door.     It's unlocked.    She ent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark, silent.    She puts her purse down.     Looks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.   She goes into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: switching on lights as she goes. Nothing. She checks the refrigerator. The sandwich she made Walter is untouched. She moves to the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door to his room.      No Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to the sidewalk.     Looks up and down the st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter?   Honey? Time to come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little GIRL on a tricycle rolls past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie honey, have you seen Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuh-uh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl continues away. Christine's concerned, but she h hit the panic button, not yet. She crosses the street to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and rings the doorbell.       The door opens and MRS. forties, emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Riley, I'm sorry to bother you at dinnertime, but I was wondering if Walter was here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know if Jamie was able to look in on him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I mentioned it to her, but she was going to a dance with some of her friends...you know how teenagers are. Is everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's fine, I just... (beat) Thank you, Mrs. Riley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine heads away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine stops at the sidewalk in front of her house, lo up and down the street, arms folded against the growing c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter...?     Walter....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts walking again. Faster now. Looking around tree and porches, anywhere a nine-year-old boy might hide. She hears children playing. Laughing. She picks up her pace, homing in on the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns the corner to find three children playing, none them Walter. She looks down the ominously empty streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her worry growing, she heads to the house.       Faster n clicking on the hard sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bursts in, leaving the door open, looking around in c he came in while she was out. Nothing. She crosses to the phone, hesitates for just a BEAT, then picks up the recei

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Operator, give me the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a long pause as she waits, looks out the window,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Lincoln Heights Division.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, hello, my name is Christine Collins, I live at 210 North Avenue 23...I'm calling to report a missing child...it's my son, he....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) How long has he been gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure...I just got home from work and...it could be since late this morning, it could be just an hour --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Have you checked around the neighborhood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Maybe he lost track of the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he always stays around the house when it starts to get dark. Can you please send someone down here? POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) I'm sorry, but our policy is that we don't dispatch units on missing child cases for twenty-four hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   But that's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Ninety-nine times out of a hundred the kid shows up by morning. We don't have the resources to go chasing every kid who runs off with his pals and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not Walter, he doesn't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) With all due respect, ma'am, every parent who calls us says the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) I'm sorry, but there's nothing I can do. I'll take your name and information, but that's all until tomorrow morning at the earliest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine walks down the street, arms wrapped around hers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he'll show up by then. They always do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues on, calling Walter's name as she disappears into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine watches out the curtained living room windows, red rimmed from worry but not from tears, not yet, as a p car finally pulls up. Neighbors look on as the officers g out and approach the house. HOLD on Christine's face, pal and worried, UNDER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our thoughts go out again to Mrs. Christine Collins, of Lincoln Heights --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Located at 5100 Coliseum Street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- whose young son, Walter Collins, disappeared almost two weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large radio microphone with the call letters KGF is ato podium, where PASTOR GUSTAV BRIEGLEB stands: fifties, bar chested, no-nonsense, a fire-and-brimstone preacher. His congregation sits in hard wooden pews, listening and nodd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though she is not a member of our congregation, we pray for her today (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. BRIEGLEB (Cont'd) as we have every day since we first learned of her situation on the radio, and in the newspapers. (beat) We are told that the Los Angeles Police Department is doing the best it can to reunite mother and child, and I am sure that is true. (beat) But given its position as the most violent, corrupt and incompetent police department this side of the Rocky Mountains, that's not saying a great deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's APPLAUSE and cheering from the pews.   He lets it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day, new bodies show up along Mulholland, or in ditches, the work of Police Chief James Davis and his so-called "gun squad." Every day the needs of honest citizens are put second to greed and personal gain. Every day, the city sinks deeper into a cesspool of fear, intimidation and corruption. Once the City of Angels, Los Angeles is now a place where our protectors have become our brutalizers...where to be the law...is to be above the law...where none dare speak truth to power. (beat) But we will not be silent. We will continue to put their offenses and their failures in full view of the public. We will not be intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place erupts into applause and cheering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE CHIEF JAMES E. DAVIS, 40s, hard-edged and tall, st looking out the window as the radio drones on behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. BRIEGLEB (on radio) Because while the "gun squad" speaks in the only language Chief Davis understands, we speak in the language of compassion, truth and strength. We speak for our fellow citizens, beaten and killed by a renegade police department. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. BRIEGLEB (on radio) (Cont'd) We speak for an innocent child, ripped from his mother's arms, now all but forgotten by the police. And that voice, my friends, will never be silenced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More cheers and applause as Davis switches off the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alarm goes off, but Christine is already awake. Stari up at the ceiling. She slowly pulls herself up and moves

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine walks past the door to his bedroom. Looks insid Goes over to the bed. Her hand lingers, touching it, UNDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're ready for this, Christine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine and Mr. Harris, the floor manager, approach the doors to the switchboard room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, if you need more time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police are doing all they can, and frankly I could use the money. It's been almost a month, and...it wouldn't do any good to find Walter and bring him home if he doesn't have a home to come back to, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles as he says it, but there's the sense that he do think Walter's coming back. It's been too long. She sense it, but moves past it, pushing open the door and entering

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As loud as before...until the operators see Christine, an the noise stops. She tries to smile, as if to say, I'm ok but can't quite manage it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several women approach and hug her as the noise level beg to climb, but nowhere near what it was a moment earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I'll leave you to it, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods as he exits, then heads off herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine moves from station to station, the noise level noticeably low. Every time she approaches an operator, th lower their voices, as if not to bother her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One operator holds up a pink request sheet. Christine sta toward her, but then the operator glances to another supe and hands it off. Knowing she has to do something about t she turns to the room and, in a firm, clear voice, says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, can I have your attention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room grows quiet.   Everyone is looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, everyone, I appreciate your consideration, but I'm not made of porcelain. I won't break down and cry if the station to station call to Kankakee doesn't go through. (a thin smile) Actually, I...promised myself that I wouldn't cry...wouldn't let myself cry...until I knew, one way or another, what.... (beat) Point is...I like the noise here. So don't be afraid to talk and...push buttons, and drop things. If it wasn't noisy, how would I know I was in the right place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She manages a thin smile as the place returns to normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Harris steps out into the lunch area where a number o the operators and supervisors are hanging out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, has anyone seen Christine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I saw her in the back office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods his thanks, and continues off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He approaches the door, slowing as he HEARS Christine ins

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- well, if you do hear anything, would you let me know? Thanks, I appreciate it. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hang-up, then dialing.   He glances in the open doorway

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine sits at a table, phone in hand, a list of phone numbers in front of her. The list reads LAS VEGAS MISSING

dialogues.speaker: PERSONS DEPARTMENT, SACRAMENTO MISSING PERSONS DEPARTMENT
dialogues.text: SAN FRANCISCO MISSING PERSONS DEPARTMENT...on and on...wi each having multiple checks beside it, indicating all the times she's called. Her lunch sits untouched beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts a check next to LAS VEGAS MISSING PERSONS DEPART then looks up as someone answers at the other end of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missing Persons department, please. (beat) Yes, hello, this is Christine Collins, I...yes, fine, thank you. I was just checking back to see if you had found any missing or lost children that might match the -- (beat) I see. No, I appreciate that, it's just...it never hurts to make sure all the lines of communication are working. I mean, that's what I do for a living, right? (beat) Well, I'll try back next week. If you do hear anything in the meantime, would you be sure to let me know? Thanks. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up and ticks another department off the list an dials again. Mr. Harris heads away, deciding that whateve it was he planned to talk to her about...it can wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missing persons department, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single car is parked in the dirt lot outside the small, roadside diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THe COOK who owns this dive is cleaning the griddle and k an eye on the only two customers in the place: a MAN and young BOY, both wearing hats, as was the custom. They're unkempt, dirty, like they've been on the road a long time They finish the last of the food as the cook approaches, off the bill and puts it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man reaches for his wallet.   Pats an empty pocket. the other pocket. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell...looks like I left my wallet at home. Can I owe it to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No credit. Pay up or I call the cops. I'm tired of bums like you coming around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to stiff you, chief. I just left my wallet at home, that's all. I'll go back and get it. Five, ten minutes tops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cook hesitates; he doesn't want the trouble of bringi in the cops, but he doesn't want to get stuck, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got any collateral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man glances at the Boy seated beside him.   The boy's is dirty, partially obscured by the hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't ask for better collateral than a man's own flesh and blood, right? (to the boy) You stay here, son, I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't give me any trouble. He's a good man to trust us like this. You just sit here while I go get my wallet. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy nods reluctantly, looks away as the man rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten minutes, then I'm calling the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man nods, exits and drives off.     The Cook squints at the Boy, then at the wall clock.     It's 2:00.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No car.   Just the empty parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 3:15. The Cook is annoyed.      He glances to the Bo won't meet his gaze. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, hell....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the phone.    Clicks the receiver a few times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Myrtle? It's Harve, down by the diner. Would you get me Sheriff Larsen? Yeah, I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He casts a sour look in the boy's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, son?    Son...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy takes a BEAT, looking out at the road.    Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before, Christine hurries from one station to another, lost in the barely-managed chaos. She stops at one statio glancing over papers, then looks over at --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the window to Mr. Harris' office, where he is talking a police officer, CAPTAIN J. J. JONES, 30s, serious, arch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slows, unable to look away, a growing dread settling her heart. Harris points out the window. Points...to her. The police captain nods and enters the switchboard room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jones heads for her, the strength goes out of Christin legs. She holds onto the a desk as he stops before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She manages a nod. Behind her eyes is the terror: he's go to tell me my son is dead. The room gets very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Captain J. J. Jones, Lincoln Park Juvenile Division. My office supervises all runaway and missing child cases, including your son's, and.... (beat, a smile) He's alive, Mrs. Collins. He was picked up two days ago by local police in De Kalb, Illinois. He's safe and unhurt. He was in the company of some drifter, we've got an APB out for him now, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she hasn't heard anything past he's safe and unhurt. almost goes to the floor as other women rush toward her, and embracing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, Christine cries, great wracking sobs, the emotion she's been fighting back all this time coming at last...he's okay...he's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones and Christine are in a police car pulling up to the train station. It moves through a police line holding bac crowd of reporters who SHOUT questions at the passing car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All these reporters...you didn't tell me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yours is a story with a happy ending, Mrs. Collins. People love happy endings. (checks watch) Train should be pulling in shortly. We'd better get a move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Christine and Jones step out, they're mobbed by the pr Jones smiles splendidly for the cameras, waves, one arm w around Christine, who looks stunned by it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...we'll have a statement for you in a little while. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JONES (Cont'd) Right now the important thing is to re-unite this little lady with her son. So if you'll excuse us....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaming, Jones escorts Christine into Union Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated on a bench is a POLICE MATRON, and beside her, the from the De Kalb diner...who we will identify henceforth "Walter." He is looking out the window at the passing sce

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that Los Angeles is where they make the Tom Mix movies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His horse is named Blue. (beat) You think they'll let me watch them make a movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, you'll have to ask. But with all this attention, who knows, maybe they will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy turns his attention back out the window as we HEA the WHISTLE of the train pulling into Union Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR the same train whistle from this side as Christin and Jones come to the ramp, POLICE CHIEF DAVIS is waiting The reporters are held back at the entrance to the platfo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins, I'd like to introduce you to Chief of Police James E. Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my, I didn't expect --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't get a lot of positive attention from the boys in the press these days, so it's good to be here when there's a positive story, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's distracted, looking off to the end of the platf where the train is starting to pull in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it you've been treated well by my boys in the department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...yes, of course, they've been great. Well, there was that part about having to wait twenty-four hours before filing a report, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technicalities aside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train stops.    Doors begin to open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...other than that, no complaints. They've all been wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, then you won't have any problem telling that to the press, and how the LAPD is concerned first and foremost with the safety of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's already running down the platform as people sta to step off the train. Jones exchanges a look with Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women.    Just a sec....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He trots off to catch up with Christine, who walks alongs the train, looking from window to window, anxious, eager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then: the Matron gets off the train, her frame momentaril blocking the view of the boy beside her...but Christine s them. With Jones not far behind, she breaks into a run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter...Walter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs toward them. The matron turns, sees her, smiles gets out of the way, revealing the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine stops. Staggers so hard she almost falls. She steps forward slowly, a hand going to her mouth. For a mo we're not sure what's going through her mind. She looks t the matron, who smiles. Looks to the boy, who smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she steps back a pace, horror sinking in as Jones co jauntily alongside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?   Aren't you going to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones freezes at the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...what are you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not my son. (beat) He's not my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm...I'm sure you're mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mistaken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been through four long, terrible months...he's gone through changes, lost weight --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know my own son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances over his shoulder to where the Chief of Police waiting, not aware of any of this, and beyond him...the p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying...I mean, you're in shock, and he's changed, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns from her, stoops down to look at the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, son?   Can you tell me your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine steps back as though slapped.     This can't be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a common name, it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where you live, Walter? Do you know your home address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy considers for a moment...then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My house is at 210 North Avenue 23, Los Angeles, California. (beat) And that's my Mommy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he RUNS to her, grabbing her around the waist, which magnifies her horror. Jones has no idea what to make of h or this, or the boy. The only thing he knows is that the chief of police is standing right over there, smiling now that he thinks he's seen a mother and child reunion. The press is nearly insane trying to get through to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins...listen to me. I know you're feeling uncertain right now, but that's to be expected...a boy this age changes so fast...but we've compensated for that in our investigation. We're experts in child identification. There's no question that this is your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Walter as you remember him. That's why it's important for you to take him home, on a...trial basis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trial basis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once you've put him back in familiar surroundings, and given yourself time to recover from the shock of his changed condition...you'll see that it is him. I swear to you, Mrs. Collins. I give you my word. Trust me...this is your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks from him to the boy...who is not terribly dissi from Walter...so that even the audience may not be entire sure if it's him or not...and part of her wants desperate to believe...the pressure is immense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's any problem, any problem at all, come and talk to me and I'll take care of it. (beat) Mrs. Collins...he has nowhere else to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an agonizing moment, then finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...look, I'll take him home, but only because I...might not be thinking clearly right now, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without giving her a moment to reconsider, he waves and t Chief of Police approaches as the press rushes toward the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an instant, they're overwhelmed by people shouting questions, flashbulbs popping, a fever of excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does it feel to have your son home, Mrs. Collins? What did you think when you saw him for the first time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was...it's...hard to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping in) It was certainly quite a shock. At first she hardly recognized him. Perfectly natural, the boy's been through quite an ordeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you feeling, son?   Bet it feels great to be home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Los Angeles Police Department is thankful for all the hard work done by the De Kalb County Sheriff's Department in helping to make this joyful reunion possible. The LAPD is dedicated to serving the public at all times, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we get a photo of mother and son, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He poses Christine and "Walter" so she is holding the boy her arms. Dazed, stunned, confused, she manages to smile the cameras. Bulbs FLASH and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- time SLOWS DOWN, the SOUND MUTED, as Christine looks a at it all as though in a dream...reporters shouting quest she doesn't hear...bulbs flashing...the boy beside her, s at it all. He looks at her, mouths the word Mommy, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the car door SLAMS and she and the boy sit side by sid The silence is in profound contrast to the madness of a m earlier. An officer gets in they drive off, passing Jones and the Chief of Police, talking quietly off to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine looks to the boy.   He smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only noise is the clock on the wall, ticking. Christi sits at one end of the table, "Walter" at the other. Stud him. He is finishing a sandwich, not meeting her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the sandwich all right? (he nods) Would you like some more milk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you need a bath. You're covered with soot from the train ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, and heads up the stairs.   She follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying a pair of pajamas, Christine comes into the hall stops in front of the bathroom door. Knocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found you a pair of pajamas. I bought them for Walter but he didn't like the fabric, so --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hears him fall and pushes the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She helps "Walter" stand, discreetly turned away from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fell.   Stupid tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hurt yourself?     Let me see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops suddenly, reacting to something we don't see. Looks slowly looks up to his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...circumcised....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his hand and marches him out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She places him against the wall where she measured Walter growth over the years. The marks put him four inches shor than the one labeled March. She looks at him, very seriou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last time I measured Walter -- the last time I measured my son -- he was four inches taller than you are right now. (beat) Who are you? (beat) What are you doing here? (beat) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says nothing.   HOLD on her look of growing desperatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones walks quickly down the hall, trying to look interes in a clutch of papers in his hands, Christine following a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who he is, or why he's saying he's Walter, but there's clearly been some kind of mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We agreed you would give him time to adjust --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's four inches shorter than Walter. Boys his age don't shrink. If anything, he should be taller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe your measurements are off. Look, I'm sure there's a reasonable explanation for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's circumcised. Walter wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones glances back, uncomfortable about discussing circum with a woman in public view. He lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins...your son was missing for four months. For at least part of that in the company of an as-yet unidentified drifter. Who knows what such a disturbed individual might have done? He could have had him...circumcised... might have --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made him smaller? Captain, please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on the move again, stepping into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and getting behind his desk as Christine follows him i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- why won't you listen to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am listening, damn it, I -- (beat, calmer) I am listening. And I understand your feelings. He's changed, no mistake. You've both been through a terrible experience. That's why he needs your support and love to bounce back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, that boy wouldn't bounce back as my son if you coated him in rubber and dropped him off the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this, Mrs. Collins? You seem perfectly capable of taking care of the boy, your work pays you enough to attend to his personal needs...so I don't understand why you're trying to run away from your responsibilities --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not running away from anything, least of all my responsibilities. I'm even taking care of that boy because right now I'm all he has. What worries me is that you've stopped looking for Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should we look someone we've already found?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you haven't found him. He's still out there somewhere, lost, maybe hurt....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His identity has been confirmed by the best minds in the field of child identification, people who know what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't? Captain, look, I don't want to cause trouble for you or the department. Honestly I don't. I know you've done everything you can...but there's been a terrible mistake, and I need your help if we're going to correct it...before it's too late. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.   Annoyed, Jones paces, then picks up the phon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara, get Dr. Tarr on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is cooking dinner when the doorbell rings. She opens the door to find a police officer and DR. EARL W. T sixties, mildly eccentric in appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins? Dr. Earl W. Tarr. Captain Jones sent me. I consult with him from time to time on juvenile cases. May I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps aside, and Dr. Tarr enters, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming. I'm surprised Captain Jones moved so quickly. I was starting to think he didn't believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm here now, and we'll put all that to rights. Where is the boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up as "Walter" comes downstairs. Noting that he said "the boy," not "your son," Christine looks relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! There he is. A handsome young man. He has your eyes, doesn't he? And a little bit of the nose. Very fit, in spite of all his travails. A very resilient boy you've got here, Mrs. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he bends down to look more closely at "Walter," Christ stiffens...she can't have heard that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Tarr, I thought you were here to help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. Captain Jones said the boy had gone through some extreme physical changes, and asked me to look in on him...to reassure you in this your time of motherly concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My "motherly concern" isn't for him because he's not my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story                           31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Statements like that will hardly help the boy's self-esteem, now will they? (beat) Captain Jones said something about a change in height...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's four inches shorter than --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, well...hardly a mystery, Mrs. Collins. We've known for some time that trauma can affect the growth of children. Given the stress of the last four months his spine may have actually shrunk. It's uncommon, but within the realm of possibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the circumcision?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very likely his abductor thought it appropriate. After all, circumcision is hygienically sound. Must have been quite traumatic at the time. No wonder he's submerged the memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, doctor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you can see, there's a perfectly sound medical explanation for all of this. But it's good for you to raise these questions. You should be apprised of all changes the lad went through during his absence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't I know whether or not he was my son? I'm his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which means you're in no position to be objective. You are looking through the prism of extreme emotion at a boy who has changed from what you remember. He isn't the same boy that left here, just as a boy who goes off to war and returns isn't the same anymore. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. TARR (Cont'd) A mother's heart, driven by intuition and emotion rather than logic, sees these changes and rebels, insists that this cannot be your son. But that doesn't change the facts. (beat) I'm willing to put my theory to the test of objectivity, Mrs. Collins... are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before she can react, he takes Walter by the hand and lea him outside. Christine follows them out to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as Dr. Tarr strides onward, the police officer and "Wa walking alongside as Christine brings up the rear. A few houses down they come to a group of CHILDREN playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, children, my name is Dr. Earl W. Tarr. I'd like to ask you some questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom says we're not supposed to talk to strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good boy. Quite right. But as you see I'm with the police, so it's all right. Now, I'm sure you know Mrs. Collins here, and her son, Walter. How many of you recognize this young boy as Walter Collins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks from one child to the other. They don't reply. Either they don't recognize him, or they're intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now, no need to be afraid. Surely you knew Walter, and played with him? So which of you can identify Walter for me, for his mother, and for the police? This officer would want you to do the right thing as good young citizens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids exchange a glance. It's clear they don't recogni the boy, but they're intimidated by the presence of Tarr the police officer. A few reluctantly raise their hands. Another of them goes to "Walter," who is shorter than he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter was as tall as me....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, precisely. He was as tall as you. Now he's not. He's lost a little height, you see. It's a thing called trauma. With luck, none of you will ever have to find out about it yourselves. So other than that, do you recognize this as your friend, Walter Collins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Tarr --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already ahead of you, Mrs. Collins; children can be intimidated. But not adults. Shall we try a neighbor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads off again, like some very tall, strange bird mar down the street. Christine exchanges a look with the kids then heads off to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tarr, Christine, Mrs. Riley, the officer and "Walter" sta on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and we'd appreciate it if you could make a positive identification for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be happy to. I saw the boy often. Come closer, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stoops down, studies "Walter's" face, turns it from s to side. Squints at him. He squints back at her. Note: she's not wearing glasses. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your time...be sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes...yes...that's Walter all right. Used to come here all the time to play with my nephew, Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Riley.   You've been a big help, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we go...Mrs. Riley, do you have the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at her watch. Holds it farther away. Can't quit focus on it. Pulls her glasses out from inside her blouse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My last concession to vanity; men don't make passes at women who wear glasses, you know. (checks the watch) Five o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Riley nods and heads inside as Christine looks to Ta who shrugs off what was just demonstrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy is much larger than a watch, Mrs. Collins. (to "Walter") Come along, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tarr takes "Walter's" hand and heads away, Christine foll anger growing in her eyes as we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is absolutely outrageous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is on the phone, "Walter" finishing up his dinner in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, I...no, listen to me, this so-called doctor paraded me around my own neighborhood like some kind of derelict mother who couldn't even recognize her own -- (beat) He found what he expected to find, what you obviously told him he would find, but it's not -- (beat) No, I am not reassured. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE (Cont'd) I thought we had an understanding, I -- (beat) That I was embarrassed isn't the issue, the point is you're wasting time when you should be looking for my son, I -- (beat) Then I want to see this report, so I can refute it, before it goes to anyone else, all right? Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up. Hard. The events of the day have her teeter on the edge, but she's holding on. She pulls herself toge and goes to the sink, furiously doing dishes for a silent BEAT before "Walter" looks up from his now-empty plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm finished. Can I go to my room now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Go on up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Walter" rises, as Christine continues to clean dishes, n looking back at him. Exhausted mentally, physically and emotionally. He goes to the door, stops, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G'night, Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine fumbles the plate and it SMASHES to the floor. turns furiously to "Walter."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop saying that! I'm not your mother! And you're not my son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves toward him, her anger coming out at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHO ARE YOU? WHY ARE YOU DOING THIS TO ME? DAMN YOU! I WANT MY SON BACK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tears off as she slumps to the floor, covering her eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my son back...god, please... make it stop...just make it stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Walter" is in bed, his back to the door, as Christine ap in the hallway. She steps into the room, sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't move.   Her voice is soft, but firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wrong to yell at you. You're still a child, and I think you don't really understand what you're doing, the hurt you're causing. Maybe this is all just some big game of pretend to you, but I need you to understand. Walter is...he's all I have, he's everything to me, and every day we lose because of this puts him further away from where I can help him. (beat) Whatever the police think, whatever the world thinks, we know the truth, don't we? We both know you're not Walter. Getting you to admit that may be the only chance I have to straighten this out before it's too late. Maybe you're afraid of getting in trouble, that you're in too deep. But you're not. You don't have to tell me who you are, you just have to tell them who you're not. Just... tell them the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't respond. She gives it a moment in case he migh open up, then rises and heads back into the hallway. She switches off the light and heads off down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pastor Briegleb is typing out his sermon for the day. He' exhausted. Looks at the clock. 6:30 a.m. He rubs tiredly at his face when he HEARS the THUMP of the newspaper bein delivered. He stands, stretches and steps out to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where the newspaper is visible on the front lawn. He p it up and starts into the rectory as he unfolds the paper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then: he slows, stunned by something he's reading.   He l up again, and hurries back into the rectory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in bed, asleep, as the telephone RINGS downstairs. glances at the clock: 6:45. She clearly doesn't want to g down to answer it...then reluctantly climbs out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone is still ringing as she picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. BRIEGLEB (on phone) Is this Mrs. Christine Collins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?   Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. BRIEGLEB (on phone) My name is Gustav Briegleb, I'm the pastor over at St. Paul's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, I heard some of your radio broadcasts after my son...you were very supportive, and I appreciate --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. BRIEGLEB (on phone) Mrs. Collins...have you seen the Times today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. BRIEGLEB (on phone) You'd better take a look. Then come by the parish in an hour for breakfast. I think we should meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to reply, but the line goes dead. She hangs up the phone, pulls her robe closer around her, and steps ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where a copy of the Los Angeles Times sits on a neighbor' front lawn. She looks around, then dashes to pick it up. She unfolds it as she heads back, then abruptly stops. Sh can't believe what she's seeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE NEWSPAPER. The headline reads Mysterious Transformation in Collins Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briegleb is eating a big breakfast. Christine, newspaper hand, is pacing, furious. She reads aloud from the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Acting on the request of the Los Angeles Police Department, Dr. Earl (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE (Cont'd) W. Tarr, child specialist, examined Walter Collins to determine the cause of his loss of weight, paleness, confusion and run-down condition noticed since the return of the boy to his mother last Saturday."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely bit of phrasing, isn't it? Noticed since the return of the boy to his mother. Not only does it state clearly that you are the boy's mother, one could infer from this that you are somehow responsible for these changes...and that the police are concerned for the boy's welfare in your hands. (beat) You should try the eggs, they're very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still reading) "I examined the boy quite thoroughly, Dr. Tarr said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Tarr is sitting at a desk and speaking to a handful o reporters, enjoying the attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and it's clear that he has something to tell. I'm sure that in time he will give his boyish story of the entire affair, but not until he has faith in his listener. And that is what is lacking: faith in the poor lad's story. In the course of my examination, I found nothing to dispute the findings by the LAPD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come he hasn't been able to tell anyone what happened while he was gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would say that the boy has either been coached or questioned to a point where he is largely confused about what happened to him during (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. TARR (Cont'd) those many months. It's possible that his mental lapse may be the result of a blow to the head or a sudden shock which brought about a possible cranial injury. I believe that this condition will pass soon. Until then, I recommend that the police department continue working with him, exposing him to whatever elements of his previous life as may help restore his memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she lowers the paper, incredulous. (And yes, what you just read was exactly what the doctor really said.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Jones promised he'd let me see the report before it went anywhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone in authority at the LAPD lied? Good heavens, I may have to go lie down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs.   She turns, looking stricken.     He sobers a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was not laughing at your situation, Mrs. Collins. It's just...after one has this sort of conversation enough times, a certain degree of hysteria begins to set in. Please, sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly, she does.      Shakes her head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are they doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To avoid admitting a mistake...that they brought back the wrong boy. (off her look) Anyone reading that with half a brain would see through it instantly. Sadly, that leaves out about half the Times' readership, but still....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE (Cont'd) I've been trying to get someone to say those words since...god, I was starting to think I was losing my mind. (beat) Thank you. At least someone believes me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no idea how many people have sat in that very chair and said those exact same words to me in relation to our friends at the Los Angeles Police Department. (beat) Mrs. Collins, I have made it my mission to bring to light all the things the LAPD would prefer no one knew anything about...a department ruled by violence, abuse, murder, corruption and intimidation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FAUX NEWSREEL FOOTAGE of Police Chief Davis speaking befo bunch of microphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Chief Davis took over the LAPD two years ago, he said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping) We will hold court on gunmen in the Los Angeles streets. I want them brought in dead, not alive, and I will reprimand any officer who shows the least mercy to a criminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd of police officers, armed with machine-guns, BLAS the hell out of a group of guys lined up against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picked fifty of the most dangerous cops on the force, gave them machine guns and permission to shoot anyone who got in their way. He called them the Gun Squad. No lawyers. No trials. No questions, suspensions or investigations. Just piles of bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another guy, beaten to a bloody pulp, is SHOVED out of a car and left in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bodies in morgues, bodies in hospitals, bodies by the side of the road, barely alive. Not because the police wanted to wipe out crime, they just wanted to get rid of the competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of cops and a couple of thugs inspect a truck carr booze over the border from Canada, pay the freight and wa as the trucks drive off in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayor Cryer and half the police force are on the take. Prostitution, gambling, bootlegging, you name it. (beat) When the gloves came off, pretty soon the rest of the department got into the brutality act. Didn't want the Gun Squad to have all the fun, after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two officers are sexually assaulting a woman on the stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more they got away with it, the worse things got, because when you give folks the freedom to do whatever they want, as God saw in the Garden of Eden, they'll do just that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Christine and Briegleb, in the rectory garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This police department does not tolerate dissent, contradiction... or embarrassment, Mrs. Collins. You have the power to embarrass them...and they don't like it. Not when they became the Heroes of the Hour the day they stood there posing with you, having rescued a lost boy from the wilderness. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. BRIEGLEB (Cont'd) (beat) They will do everything they can to discredit you. I've seen it happen too many times to start going blind now. That's why I wanted to see you, so you'd know what you were getting into...and how to fight them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Briegleb...I appreciate what you're saying, and what you're doing...but I'm not on a mission. The only thing I want is to find my son, that's all, and I just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of mothers' sons ended up being sacrificed to expediency around here, Mrs. Collins. Yours wouldn't be the first. Do this right, and maybe yours will be the last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up from the table, paces the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they honestly thought I was wrong, that'd be one thing...but if they don't care, if they're just trying to cover it up....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the article, waves it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is their attempt to win by framing the discussion their way. "Why, of course it's her son...yes, there have been changes...we're looking into it, and isn't it strange that they happened after the boy got home?" (beat) They're putting you in the position of having to disprove what they're saying...and that's hard. Most people believe what they hear from the police or the government. If you play it their way, you...and your son...are going to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes her eyes for a BEAT, then looks to him, her vo firmer, her decision made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I have to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change the rules of engagement. Re- define the argument. They brought in their expert, so you bring in yours. You have an advantage they don't. You know your son better than they ever will, and in that knowledge is the proof you need. (beat) Get that information, put it out there. Make them respond to you, not the other way around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, walks toward her, puts his hands on her shoul Giving her strength...but also his concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once people side with the police, it's a hard climb...but even in a town as loud as this one, the voice of truth can be heard...if you're willing to take it all the way in spite of the dangers...and they are very real, Mrs. Collins, make no mistake. Once you open the book on these people, you're going to be looking over your shoulder every day, maybe for the rest of your life. (beat) You up to it, Mrs. Collins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks in her eyes...and she meets his gaze levelly. answer is evident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in a dentist's office. Christine is waiting for a B before the door opens, and DR. JOHN MONTGOMERY emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had two cavities that needed filling. He put up a fight, but I took care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He casts a look back at the closed door, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son's upper front teeth were separated by a small muscle. Made them sit about an eighth of an inch apart. The boy in that room has no such gap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does a gap like that get smaller with age? Because that's what they'll say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In some cases, yes, it's possible. But the muscle between Walter's teeth prevents that from happening. They can never come together without an operation to sever the muscle, and I can tell you right now that he has never had such an operation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be willing to sign a letter saying that officially?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon my language, but...hell, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears an OS moan from the inner office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like the anesthetic is wearing off. (starts in, pauses) On the other hand, maybe I'll write that letter first. Give the little fella something to think about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small, with wooden desks, chalkboard, all the basics. "Wa stands in front of MRS. FOX, fifties, wearing severe glas and an equally severe expression. Christine stands nearby

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? What do you think? Is that the Walter Collins that you remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is, he's changed enormously. (to "Walter") Do you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but even teachers have names. What's mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember. I know you, but I don't remember your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Mrs. Fox.   Now, take your seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Walter" hesitates, then takes a seat.    The other kids

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say take a seat. I said take your seat. Your assigned seat. You must know which one it is, you sat there for over a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Walter" tries another vacant seat. There are only three vacant seats in the room. More laughter from the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try again. Here's a hint: There's only one more empty seat left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits.   Mrs. Fox looks to Christine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins, if that's your son, I'll eat my yardstick. Not only will I put that in writing, I'll swear to it in a court of law and in front of President Calvin Coolidge himself if I have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, Christine allows a hopeful smile.
