dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are low. Christine sits on the floor, sorting through a box containing artifacts of affection: class pr made by Walter, trees and houses and clay dogs; a heart-s card Mother's Day card, hand-made, with I Love You, Mommy carefully printed on the front. She runs her finger over tracing the impression left by his pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to cry, and a tear falls onto the pencil drawi She frantically dabs at it, trying to preserve it from distortion...then sets it down and covers her face, weepi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold, wet knot of reporters and photographers are waiti in the rain on the steps to City Hall. Christine sits in car with Briegleb, looking at it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you tonight at eight for my broadcast. I'll leave the back door open and a light on. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, exits the car and walks up the steps to the fro of City Hall as he drives off. She stands before the pres looks at them for a moment, then begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. My name is Christine Collins. On March 10th, my nine year old son, Walter Collins, disappeared. A four month investigation resulted in a boy being brought to Los Angeles from De Kalb, Illinois. They told me, and all of you, that this boy was my son. They were wrong. (beat) The Los Angeles Police Department made a mistake...a terrible mistake. The boy they found is not my son. That is the reason for the supposed "transformation." I have letters from his dentist, his teachers and others confirming that this boy is not my son. The letters are being reprinted now, and I should have them for you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashbulbs pop, dazzling her.    She composes herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have given the police department every opportunity to admit their mistake and renew the search for my son. Since they have refused to do so, I have no choice but to present my case before the public. I hope this will persuade the police to finish the job they started, and bring my son home to me. (beat) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the reporters start to shout out questions, we PAN ACR to a BEAT COP who has been watching. He goes quickly to a police call-box, unlocks it and picks up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glass door to Captain Jones' office is closed, but we SEE him on the phone. Finally, he hangs up and comes out the office. His tone is cold but neutral...we think this could go either way. He stops an officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morelli, I want you to find the Collins woman and get her here. Bring her in the back way, and have a couple of matrons standing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads off as Jones goes into his office, closing the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car pulls up to the curb, and Christine and "Wal emerge from the back seat. They dash through the rain to back door, followed by the 1st Cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we using the back door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain's orders.     Front's jammed with reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She allows a moment of quiet satisfaction as she's led in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where she's directed to a wooden bench. A nearby clock re 3:45. She sits, "Walter" silent beside her. In the BG, th Desk Sergeant puts a call on hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey...anybody want to take a call from the Royal Canadian Mounties? Ybarra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DETECTIVE LESTER YBARRA, thirties, good looking, glances

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd they do, lose a moose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They need a juvenile living here illegally deported back to Canada. He's living with his cousin on some ranch near Riverside, in Wineville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll take it, got nothing better to do....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra takes the call as Jones' calls from his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine starts to take "Walter's" hand when a matron ap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave the boy for now.   We'll look after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands "Walter" over to the matron, then enters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the door open and indicates for Christine to si She does. He paces, working up to what he's going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've put us through quite a bit of trouble, Mrs. Collins. This situation has become an embarrassment for the entire department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't my intention to embarrass anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not. You just told the papers we can't tell one boy from another as a compliment for the months we spent working on your case. Are you trying to make fools out of us? Is that it? Do you enjoy this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not. I had to get your attention, I had to make you understand...he's not my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He circles, closing in on her. She becomes aware that the door is open, and he's doing this for the benefit of anyo who might be listening in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story                            49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what your problem is? You want to shirk your responsibilities as a mother. You enjoyed being a free woman, didn't you? Enjoyed not having to worry about a young son. You could do what you wanted, go where you wanted, see anyone you wanted. But then we found your son. Brought him back. And now he's an inconvenience. That's why you cooked up this whole scheme, to try and throw him to the state, let the state raise him for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Even the boy says he's your son. Why would he do that? How would he know to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! All I know is that he's lying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe so. Maybe he is a liar. But that's how he's been trained, isn't it? Lying was born in both of you. You're a liar and a troublemaker and if you ask me you've got no business walking the streets of Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because either you know you're lying, or you're not capable of knowing if you're lying or telling the truth. So which is it, Mrs. Collins? Are you a derelict mother? Or just nuts? Because from where I sit, those are the only options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to sit here and take this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones stands between her and the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to bring in experts? Doctors? Well, I can do that too. (calling OS) Matron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, and a POLICE MATRON enters. He looks back Christine, his voice low, his anger replaced by cool determination. This scene is about to take an abrupt chan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins...do you still insist that the boy out there is not your son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods to the matron, who moves to restrain her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Matron cuffs Christine's hands behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't struggle, ma'am.   You'll only hurt yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLICK, and the handcuffs are in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the matron) You are to convey the prisoner to the Los Angeles County General Hospital Psychopathic Ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...wait, you can't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still to matron) Make the following entry in the booking department: Defendant states she has been deceived by police and others, and that they have given her a boy and tried to make her think it is her son when she says it is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is led, in handcuffs, into a waiting police van (VO has been taken verbatim from the police report.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins has been known to us since about March 10, 1928, when she reported her nine-year-old son Walter missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunned and dazed Christine rides in the back of the va

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy was gone until July, 1928. Since his return, she has complained that he is still missing, and has made repeated requests that he be found, saying, "This is not my Walter," even though positive identification has been established.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police van enters the hospital at 1200 North State St

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sterile, dreary, white-on-white place where in the background, we can HEAR the sounds of the insane crying o The matron leads a stunned Christine to the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She suffers from paranoia, delusions of persecution, and dislocation from reality. She may be a threat to herself or others. We recommend that she be conveyed to the psychopathic ward for treatment and observation until her senses can be restored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The matron stops before the desk.   The NURSE barely look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got another code twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collins.   Christine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...please, this is a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to matron) Certifying officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain J. J. Jones, Lincoln Heights division.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forced calm) Please...you have to listen to me. The police are doing this to punish me. They tried to force this boy on me and tell me he was my son, but it wasn't my son, and now they say I'm crazy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, noting the looks exchanged between the nurse a the matron. Her story sounds insane, even to her. She beg to realize the depth of her predicament.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, god...oh god, please, no....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you continue to struggle I'll have to put you in a straitjacket. Do you want that? (she shakes head) Good. Then behave yourself. (to orderlies) Code twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The matron turns Christine over to two large male ORDERLI who take her by the arms and lead her into the psycho war

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please, you have to listen to me...wait...please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They force-march her down the hall, the screams of the in growing louder, falling deeper into the nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is ushered into the room by a NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take off your clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Physical examination, body cavity search and de-lousing. Required for all new patients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse begins putting on a pair of rubber gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not necessary --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can remove your clothes yourself, or I can have the orderlies do it for you. Which do you prefer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly, Christine begins to remove her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON CHRISTINE'S FACE as she stands in a spray of water and disinfectant, some coming from the showerhead above, some from a hose sprayed on her by the Nurse in BG. Christine' eyes are closed, trying to shut out the sense of violatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spread your legs. (a beat) Wider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biting her lip, Christine complies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wet hair plastered to her face, dressed in a hospital gow Christine is led down a long hall by the Nurse. As she pa the closed doors, we HEAR women weeping, talking to thems crying out, screaming, beating on the walls. Fingers poke through narrow viewing slits in the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse pulls out a key-ring and unlocks one of the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine enters --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bare, forbidding, four white walls and a narrow slit of a window. It's a two-person room. Sitting on the other bed another PATIENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your room. The doctor's left for the day. He'll see you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning? But...wait, I've got to talk to someone in authority --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My room...no, no...this is...this is MY room....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then if I could just use the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone privileges are earned by good behavior. You're not allowed newspapers, magazines, radio, books or sharp objects. This is for your own good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse exits, closing and locking the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...please! There's been a terrible mistake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. She's alone with the other Patient, who doesn't much like the noise and disturbance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My room. My room.       They SAID it was MY ROOM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MY ROOM!     MY ROOM!   MY ROOM!   MY ROOM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts SCREAMING.    Christine covers her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We slowly PULL AWAY from the narrow window, and the sound screaming, into the late afternoon rain and growing darkn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone truck sits beside the road, hood open, steam comin from the radiator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GORDON NORTHCOTT, thirties, thin and angular, finishes wo on the car as a police car approaches. The detective we s earlier, Ybarra, is inside. He rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overheated, that's all.   She'll be fine in a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, could you give me a hand? I'm trying to find a place called the Northcott Ranch, up by Wineville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he answers, Gordon moves casually to the back of the o truck to get a rag to wipe his hands. There is a GUN on t floor of the trunk. Gordon picks it up inside the rag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Northcott Ranch...oh yeah. You're almost there. Follow this west for about two, three miles. Then the next right. That'll bring you right to it. Something going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just looking into a juvenile matter. Thanks for the help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra drives away. As soon as he's out of sight, Gordon slams the hood, runs to the driver's side and starts the still steaming. He drives off as fast as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, low house, stonework and brick and wood, behind a large open area cluttered with junked cars. At the far en of the open area is a chicken coop, about fifteen feet lo Ybarra drives up in front of the house, gets out, looks a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone is watching as Ybarra moves toward the main house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra glances off to a rustling SOUND, and follows it to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few chickens inside, held back by wire. An ax is nearby its stained edge buried in an old wooden stump. A corner the coop seems to have come down and been crudely repaire

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As suddenly someone runs across the dirt yard into the ho SLAMMING the door. Ybarra runs to the porch, tries the do Locked from the inside. He pounds on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the police. I have a warrant for a minor named Sanford Clark. Open the door and stand aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reply.   He braces himself and KICKS open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door BANGS against the wall. Flies buzz around the pl The kitchen is in shadows, but there's no question it's a mess. Ybarra moves cautiously through the kitchen. No sou except the wood creaking beneath his feet as he enters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old, musty, shadowed. The ticking of an old grandfather c There's no one in sight. Ybarra moves down the hall, glan into two adjoining rooms. Nothing. He continues into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtains drawn, dark, cocooned against the outside world. Ybarra makes a circuit of the room, then STOPS at a creak wood from a CLOSET. He moves toward it. Pauses. Reaches for the doorknob...as suddenly a clock CHIMES loudly and closet explodes outward and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- SANFORD CLARK, 15, runs out. He slams into Ybarra, kno him down. They go down in a tumble of limbs, wrestling on the floor as Sanford tries to escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! Stop it or I'll push your face through the floor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathing hard, Sanford finally stops struggling.   Ybarr cuffs Sanford's hands behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford stands, and as Ybarra leads him out, we PAN TO a and a photo that shows Sanford Clark and a man we recogni as the one we saw by the road earlier: Gordon Northcott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra locks Sanford in the car, then climbs in the drive side. He checks a cut on his face in the rear-view mirror

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...what the hell's wrong with you? Don't you know assaulting a cop is against the law?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does it make now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're just sending you back to Canada, son, it isn't the end of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't just stay in the U.S. as long as you want, pal. We've got a orders to send you back home, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Sanford starts laughing. It's a nearly hysterica laugh, half fear and half relief...Ybarra isn't there for reasons he thought. Ybarra is puzzled by his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't know Canada was that funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra puts the car into gear and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough to ESTABLISH, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gustav Briegleb sits behind the microphone, waiting to go the air. He looks at the clock. 7:59. Glances to an AIDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No word from Mrs. Collins? (aide shakes head) Get on down to her house, make sure she's all right. If she's not there, call the LAPD, see what they know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aide hurries off as Briegleb turns back to the microp and touches a switch. The ON THE AIR lamp glows to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Pastor Gustav A. Briegleb of St. Paul's Presbyterian Church, bringing you the Lord's word on radio KGF. Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is in bed, wide awake, the sounds of the asylum somewhat lessened now. Her face is dimly lit by moonlight

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had hoped to have a guest with us tonight, but apparently she has been delayed. Since she can't be here to tell you what she told the press this afternoon, I'll fill in the best I can. I'm going to tell you what happened, and I'm going to keep telling you right here, every night...until someone does something about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On her face, we go to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon Northcott makes his way to the ticket booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like a ticket to Canada. Alberta or Vancouver, whatever's leaving tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have anything going that far tonight. Best I can do is put you on a train for Seattle. From there you can transfer to one of the locals or drive across the border.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Round-trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vender moves away to pull the ticket. Gordon glances a cop heading his way. Stiffens. The cop continues past him. Gordon relaxes as the vender slides the ticket acros

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be fifteen dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon pays for the ticket and heads toward the boarding

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just enough to establish the transition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is on top of the bed, eyes open, not having sle all night. She's staring at the woman on the next cot. TH woman is staring back at her. The second-hand on a clock behind protective chicken-wire passes 8:00 and a loud BEL goes off, announcing the start of the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear doors being unlocked up and down the hall. Christ stands, pulls her hair back, and catches her reflection i the window: pale, drawn, smudged, and in a hospital gown. looking like someone who actually belongs in this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and she steps into the hall as a NURSE pas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see the doctor?   Or someone in charge --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast is half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the hall. The doctor will call for you when he's ready. (beat) Go or stay, either way I lock the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine doesn't want to stay, so she moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine and the other patients sit at long tables. A fe talk in quiet whispers, but most eat silently, staring va ahead. Some have scars showing lobotomies or electro- convulsive (shock) therapy. It's a scary bunch. Christine isn't eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another female patient, CAROL DEXTER, thirties, watches Christine then slides closer. A BEAT, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should eat. Eating is normal. You got to do everything you can to look normal. That's the only chance you've got. Besides, you'll need the strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is startled by the level-headedness of the advi from someone she assumed was probably nuts. Reluctantly, begins eating the cold-looking oatmeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Carol Dexter.    What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine.     Christine Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine reacts to the taste of the food, which is awful

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish it all.    I know it's hard, but you have to   try. Lunch isn't as bad. Close,    but not as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be here that long. As soon as I can talk to a doctor, they'll realize there's been a terrible mistake and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that always works. (beat, quieter) I heard them talking. You're here on a code twelve, police action. The doctors, the staff, they figure that if the police sent you here, there must be a good reason for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll just have to prove that I'm not insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? How? The more you try to act sane, the crazier you start to look. If you smile too much, you're delusional or stifling hysteria. If you don't smile, you're depressed. If you're neutral you're emotionally withdrawn and potentially catatonic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to have given this a great deal of thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have. Don't you get it? You're code twelve. So am I. We're here for the same reason. (beat) We pissed off the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine sits back heavily, starting to understand the w more than she ever wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you thought you were the only one? (points os) The lady over there was married to a cop who kept beating her up. When she tried to tell somebody, they sent her here. And that one? The police beat the crap out of her brother, broke both his arms. When she complained to the papers, they picked her up and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...work nights. (Chris doesn't get it) I mean, I work nights. Downtown. In some of the clubs. You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gets through.   Hooker.   Christine nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one client started hitting me, and he wouldn't stop. So I filed a complaint. Turns out he was a cop. Next thing I know, I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how can they --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding right? Hey, everybody knows women are fragile, right? They're all emotions, no logic, nothin' goin' on upstairs. And sometimes, like when they say something that's a little, y'know, inconvenient...they just go fucking nuts, pardon my French. If we're insane, nobody has to listen to us. I mean, who are you going to believe, some crazy woman trying to destroy the integrity of the force, or a police officer? Then once they get us in here, we either learn to behave, and shut up, or -- (beat) Or you don't go home...or you go home like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods to an older woman whose upper temples are marred surgical scars. Lobotomized. Christine turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better finish up your oatmeal. Want to look sane for the doctors. Then I want to hear what they nailed you for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Numb with horror, Christine forces down the oatmeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford Clark sits near several other juveniles being hel Pensive, nervous, he watches a kid absently tapping a rul against his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FEATURE the ruler.   Rising.   Falling.   Tapping.   Then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- on Sanford as we hear it continuing to tap OS.     PUS his face. Then, suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- on a HATCHET, rising and falling in tune with the rule tapping. There's blood on the hatchet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon Northcott's eyes glitter insanely as he brings the hatchet down again and just as it comes right AT US we fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sanford CRIES OUT with the memory. We PULL BACK to see the others in the room staring at him. He turns away, won meet their gaze. Something's terribly wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, an ADMINISTRATOR comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark...Sanford Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford rises, goes to the Administrator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paperwork's come through. You'll be deported back to Canada day after tomorrow. The police there will to decide what to do with you next. I hope your stay here has convinced you not to try crossing the border illegally in future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to turn and walk away when:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I...I want to talk to the officer who brought me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he has far more important things to do than --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.   It's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Administrator senses that he's sincere, and troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's off-duty until tomorrow, but... I'll see what I can do. No promises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, the administrator heads away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon Northcott is hitch-hiking by the side of the road. truck approaches, passes him...then slows and stops. Gord runs up to the truck as the DRIVER leans out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vancouver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hop in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon climbs into the truck and goes to shove his bag un the seat...when something metallic bangs underneath. He l out a short length of metal pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about that, pal. Just a little insurance. A couple of guys tried to hijack my truck a few years ago so they could run booze over the border. You can't be too safe, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I surely do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon smiles, moves as if to hand the pipe back...and su SLAMS it DOWN on the Driver's head...over and over and ov Blood splatters his face. Breathing hard, Gordon shoves t Driver out of the truck into the undergrowth then drives

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing a bandage on one arm, Christine is escorted down hall by one of the nurses. She's led into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where DOCTOR JONATHAN STEELE stands as Christine enter He's in his fifties, heavy-set, serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins...Dr. Jonathan Steele. Please, have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse leaves. Christine notes that there are three ch in a row. Could be a test. She sits in the middle chair. Sits as straight as she can. Trying to look sane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope your stay has been comfortable so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.   Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I'd think it would be quite difficult at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching herself) Well, it was. Difficult, I mean. But comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a note of this. She grimaces. This isn't going well. He motions to the bandage on her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see they took a blood test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasserman Test. To check for syphilis. Apparently it can affect the mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idea that someone thinks you should be checked for syphilis...did that upset you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not at all. I'm sure it's... standard procedure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles a forced smile.   Trying to appear level-heade

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Exactly. Standard procedure. We have to cover all bases, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering her bases) But...at the same time...I imagine that it would be...would probably be upsetting to...some people that someone else might...suspect that of them. (beat) However inappropriate that might be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flashes another wan smile. He makes another note, pic up the report on his desk, glances it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to your file, you believe the police have substituted a fake boy for your son. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say they substituted a fake boy, just...not the right boy. (beat) They brought back the wrong boy. Not my son. He's still missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts pulling out papers from his file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's strange...you see, I have here a newspaper article with a photo of you at the train station, welcoming your son home. That is you in the photo, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So at first he was your son, but now he's not your son. (beat) Has this been going on for a long time? People...changing, becoming something other than what they are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People don't change, doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think people change?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the police...they're not out to persecute you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police are here to protect us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods. She's trying to say what she thinks he wants to hear. It's a chess match that ends with:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's odd, because according to the head nurse, when you were admitted you accused the police of conspiring to do this deliberately, to punish you. So either she and the interns are also conspiring against you...or you're changing your story. (beat) Do you often have trouble telling reality from fantasy, Mrs. Collins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits back.    Christine's face tells the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining.    The Administrator enters with Detective

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to bring you out in this weather, detective, but the boy has been quite insistent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, I'll just see what he has to say so I can go home and get dry. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single table, two chairs. Sanford sits quietly, nervous as Ybarra hangs his wet coat up on a hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining cats, dogs and democrats out there, so this better be worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits across the table from Sanford, lights up a cigare Sanford's mouth works for a moment, but nothing comes out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I -- this isn't easy, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long BEAT.   Sanford composes himself, begins:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cousin's Gordon Northcott. He owns the ranch where you found me. He let me live there in exchange for watching the place when he was gone, doing chores, stuff like that. Said I could stay on as long as I wanted to. I figured that also meant I could leave whenever I wanted to, but he wouldn't let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying he held you prisoner? (sanford nods) Bull. When I got to the ranch you were running around free as a jaybird. Could've left any time you wanted. So what's this, some kind of story to cover why you were in the country illegally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...no, it's nothing like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't have time for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, please.    He said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   What did he --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said that if I tried to leave, he'd kill me! (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SANFORD (Cont'd) You don't understand, you don't know what he's like, what he...what we did...what he made me do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford is in tears by now. Ybarra realizes that there's something real going on here, and backs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, lets start at the beginning. What did he make you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford closes his eyes.    Takes a long beat.   Finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him and me...me and Gordon, we... (beat, softly) ...we killed some kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra freezes, the cigarette not moving in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to, I swear...he made me help him, said if I didn't he'd kill me, too. Please, you gotta help me...I'm scared...I don't want to go to Hell for killing kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...I never knew their names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks about it for a moment. The fact that he has to them all up is almost as chilling as what follows next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About...twenty, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's true, I swear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...thereabouts...I kinda stopped counting after a while, and Gordon said one or two might've gotten away, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody can just up and kill twenty kids --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did...yeah, we did that....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford looks off, pauses, then, softly and slowly....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most times we'd bring back just one or two...sometimes as many as three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon is at his truck, the same one we saw earlier, chec the engine as Sanford looks on nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always knew when he was getting ready 'cause he'd go through the car and clean it up, make sure the tires were good, the engine...he was always afraid something'd break down and we'd be caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon slams the hood shut, looks to Sanford.    Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kid is walking down the street, playing idly, by himsel as the truck starts to approach from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd go a different direction every time, never hit the same part of town twice. Sometimes we'd go for hours, just driving around, until we found somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck comes beside the kid and Gordon leans out the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd use all kinds of different stories. Sometimes he'd say he had free tickets for the circus, or he was looking for a lost dog...that one worked real good. Other days --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are, we've been looking for you like mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH-IMAGE: to a different kid, a different street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Your folks, they got in an accident. They sent us to find you. They're hurt real bad. The police took 'em to the hospital, but they didn't have time to come find you, so we said we'd do it. Now come on, hurry...we gotta get to the hospital, see your folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH-IMAGE: Yet another kid, who hesitates, looks to San

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of kids won't get in a car alone with a stranger, but when he's got a kid there with him, that made it easier. (beat) They'd look to me, and figure if I was safe, they would be too. That's why he needed me, see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.     Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH-IMAGE: Back to the first kid, who takes one last BE then gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time they got in the truck, it was like I wanted to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good boy! Now hold on, it's a long drive and we gotta fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the truck heads off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, as soon as we got back to the ranch...they went in the coop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy, crying, is tossed into the chicken coop.   There two other boys there, also crying and screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some days he'd do 'em right off. Other days, he'd wait, pick up a few more, keep 'em in the coop until he had like four or five, 'cause -- (beat) -- 'cause he liked to hear 'em scream all at once. Like they were some kinda chorus. And then....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon, eyes insane with blood lust, stumbles toward the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and then....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford looking on, afraid to move, the single overhead l in the coop swinging wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon grabbing an ax.    Raising it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Sanford's eyes, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ax begins to fall in SLOW MOTION and --

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: -- as the long ash at the end of Ybarra's cigarette, TUMB to the floor in SLOW MOTION, end over end, SHATTERING whe hits the floor and bringing us back to full speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes...sometimes he'd leave one or two of 'em alive...barely anyway...and tell me...finish 'em. Finish 'em...or I'll finish you. (beat) And I did...I did...oh god...oh, sweet Jesus...I killed 'em...I killed 'em...I killed 'em....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then: silence, except for Sanford's sobbing. Ybarra reali he hasn't been breathing. He tries to find his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These...uhm...these kids...do you think...if you saw them again, do you think you'd recognize them? (sanford nods) Just a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to his coat and pulls out a batch of photos of mi kids bound with a rubber band. Hands it to Sanford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't updated these in a while, but still, it should be.... (beat) Just go through...and if you see any faces you recognize, put it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford takes the photos.   Starts going through them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photo, a face, goes down on the table. Then another. A third. With each photo slapped down the SLAP gets louder, BOOMING at us. Another photo. Another. Row after row. He's crying, sobbing, but still putting down photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he SLAMS down the last one and   half-falls, half-st out of his chair, sobbing...goes to   the corner of the r and slides down the wall until he's   sitting in a fetal position, hands covering his face.    Sobbing uncontrolla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Numb, Ybarra goes to the table, picks up a photo. Looks a it. Turns it over to the name, then picks up another. The a third. When he picks up the fourth photo and turns it o he stops, staring at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name on the back of the photo is WALTER COLLINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones is on the phone, pissed and getting more pissed by moment. INTERCUT between Jones and Ybarra in juvenile hal during the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone soft in the head, Les?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's playing you! He knows he's in trouble, so he's come up with some cock and bull story about how he was forced to stay in the country --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, sir, I don't think so. You didn't see him, the kid's scared half out of his mind --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picked the Collins kid! We found him, remember? Haven't you been reading the papers? (beat) Or maybe you have, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He backhands a newspaper on his desk, headlined DISTRAUGH MOTHER CLAIMS POLICE RETURNED WRONG CHILD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, if you'd just listen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then a secretary sticks her head in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, captain, but he's here again...that reverend, Briegleb. He's asking about Christine Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the sonofabitch to get the hell off police property before I have him arrested for disturbing the peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried. He said he's not leaving... him, or his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a disturbance off-screen and she goes to deal wit as Jones gets further wound up to ninety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's drawn to the window by the sound of voices. He peeks through the slats. Several dozen placard-carrying parishi and members of the Women's Temperance League are standing the street, beating drums and calling Christine's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus jumped down....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He realizes he's still on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra? Listen. You're not to do anything except come back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, department policy requires that all allegations of homicide have to be investigated. And these are kids, for chrissakes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Departmental policy is what I say it is, you got that? Now I'm ordering you to get your ass back here with that kid, you got that? You bring him here and you talk to no one, got it? Nobody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the phone down.   CUT BACK TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Ybarra in juvenile hall, agonizing over this. Finally, his voice resigned, he looks into the interrogation room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones has come out into the hall, where Briegleb, several supporters and a handful of reporters are standing at the receiving officer's desk. They approach quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Captain Jones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell have you done with Christine Collins? Don't try and lie your way out of it. I talked to several neighbors who saw her being driven off in a police car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins has been placed in protective custody following a mental breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her statements and behavior have been found to be consistent with a delusional state of mind that could make her a danger to herself or others. In the public interest, we are looking after her son while she gets the help she clearly needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, we're withholding that information to respect the privacy of the family. But I can assure you that she's getting the best treatment available. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads back the way he came as the others shout questio after him, held back by other police officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patients are being corralled into a line that extends to barred window where a nurse is dispensing pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Line-up for medication.    Line up for medication....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is nudged forward by an orderly, Carol beside h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.   Move up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of medication?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kind that's good for you.    Help you relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's nudged to the window, where a nurse hands out a pil and water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to relax...I'm fine, and I won't take something unless I know what it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orderly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just listen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- we can force-feed it to you if that's what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine sees Dr. Steele, breaks away and rushes to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor...Doctor Steele --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's going on, but I'm not taking anything until --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves off into an adjoining room. Carol Dexter, next i line, takes her pill...but keeps an eye on Christine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to his desk as she stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have anything wrong with me that I should have to take medication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing wrong with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls a typed letter out of his desk, slides it across

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you shouldn't have any trouble signing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks it up, reads as he continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story                            77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By signing, you certify that you were wrong when you stated the boy returned by the police was not your son. It further stipulates that the police acted properly in sending you here for observation and absolves them of all responsibility for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't sign it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then your condition is not improved. (beat) Sign it, and you can be out of here first thing tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't sign it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tears up the sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was not wrong! That boy is not my son! And I am not going to stop telling the truth about this! And you're not going to stop me, and the police aren't going to stop me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins, you're becoming agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I will tear down the walls of this place with my bare hands if I have to, but one way or another --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orderly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orderly appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patient is disturbed, hyperactive and is threatening the staff. See to it she is properly sedated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She BURSTS past the orderly, running into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: running, pursued by orderlies, two more blocking her way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I won't let you!     Someone, please, help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They TACKLE her and bring her down. She struggles as the others look on, and you can see in their eyes that they d like what they're seeing, there's rage --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and a furious Carol Dexter comes to her aid. She JUMPS into the struggle. Biting. Kicking. Scratching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steele comes on the run just as the orderlies peel Carol the fight, spinning her around to face Steele, who SLAPS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of this! This is none of your business! (to the rest) This is police business! You'll stay out of it if you know what's good for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks to Carol, Christine restrained behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd think you had enough trouble with the law just being a whore, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles. She gets a hand free and SLUGS him, hard, a na slicing his cheek. He touches his face. It comes back wit blood. Then he looks to the orderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attacking a staff member. Room eighteen. Electro-convulsive therapy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orderly hauls Carol off, kicking and screaming, as Christine is moved toward the nurse's station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol!   No, leave her alone!    What're you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They force a pill in her mouth, following with water as t hold her nose, forcing her to swallow. She chokes, swallo They march her down the hall as Steele returns to his off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol....!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The electro-shock room. Carol struggles against the order who force her down onto the gurney. A nurse behind her ap conductor jelly to her temples as another orderly shoves rubber bite-guard into her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a pair of metal pincers, points covered in cloth, ar pressed against her temples. A button is pushed...and her body goes RIGID as a jolt of electricity blasts through h body. (This was, remember, fairly common practice for vio behavior in the 1920s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she passes out, her eyes rolling up in her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is peering out the narrow slot in her door as s sees Carol being wheeled down the hall and put into her b Christine, sobbing, collapses slowly to the floor, caught a nightmare and unable to wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Ybarra is sitting at his desk, not happy about lot of his life at this moment. He's turning over the pho of the missing kids identified by Sanford Clark and arran them on his desk the way you might arrange cards, playing solitaire. He looks up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to see Sanford being led out of one of the holding are hands cuffed, clothes in his hands. Being transferred to waiting bus. The two exchange a look. Ybarra looks away. Sanford continues toward the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, in agony, Ybarra can't take it any more. He rise goes to the officer standing by the door to the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, I'll take it from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need him for questioning.   Come on....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads Sanford away, then stops two passing officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two...you've just been requisitioned for backup. I'll explain on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries off.   The officers follow, not sure what's up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine sits beside Carol's bed. She's awake but dazed. Christine dabs a wet cloth against her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have done that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with difficulty) Wanted...to. Felt...good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol takes her hand, holds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost...two babies...to back alley doctors...no choice.... (beat) Never had...the chance...to fight for them. You do. Don't stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't...I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck them...and the horse...they rode in on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine manages a thin smile, despite her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's hardly appropriate language for a lady, now is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, yeah...there are times...that's exactly the right thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you've got...nothing left to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine touches her face, and we know she's heard this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two squad cars pull up to the ranch. Ybarra and the other officers get out, guns up, not knowing if Gordon is still there or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move quickly through the area, checking the house. Everything's dark, silent. One officer runs into the hous there's a long pause...then he pokes his head out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra goes back to the car, opens the door.   Sanford em

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.     Show me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford hesitates, then starts toward a nearby barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides the door open and walks to the far end. The dir here is a strange white-yellow color. Ybarra follows, sti keeping a wary eye out for trouble. He looks down at wher Sanford has stopped. Several bags marked LYE are nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This it?   You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford nods.   Ybarra edges toward a shovel, hands it to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dig. (off sanford's look) You put 'em in the ground, you can take 'em out of the ground. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford takes the shovel and starts cutting out sections dirt and lye, dust rising around them. Ybarra watches, pensively, as the other officers edge their way in. He's looking the other way when one of the officers reacts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy god....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra glances back...to see a child's shoe being unearth And beside it...bones. And then...a skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it in...get the coroner and every officer in a twenty mile radius here inside the hour. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YBARRA (Cont'd) Then put out an APB on Gordon Stewart Northcott, the info is in my car. Go on....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer races out of the barn as Ybarra looks to Sanf who is still digging, crying as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can stop now, son. (he doesn't) You can stop now. It's over. We can take it from here. It's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sobbing, Sanford drops the shovel and collapses on the gr hands covering his face, crying in great, heaving sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patients are lined up outside their rooms for inspect Steele passes down them in review. Stops in front of Christine, who looks exhausted, worn, pale, her eyes bloodshot...but still defiant. He glances to the orderlie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Privacy, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orderlies move all of the other patients away, except Christine, who shares a glance with Carol. Several other orderlies remain. He glances at her chart in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you've still been refusing medication, requiring force-feeding. I see they switched to a rubber tube. I hear that can quite uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't answer. Her eyes never leave his.     He pull another copy of the letter out of the folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six days, Mrs. Collins, and no progress. We may have to go to more...strenuous therapies. (beat) Unless you're willing to prove you're doing better...by signing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds it up in front of her. She focuses first on it, then on him...and finally, her spine where it needs to be even if the rest of her is in shambles, looks at him and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you....and the horse...you rode in on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, shrugs, puts the letter back in the folder.   Tu to the orderlies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They GRAB her and start muscling her down the hall, Chris kicking and screaming as they go. Steele continues out to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where he comes through the double-barred door just as Gus Briegleb charges in the front door, carrying a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I WANT TO TALK TO SOMEBODY IN CHARGE! RIGHT NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHO'S IN CHARGE HERE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steele approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm head doctor on duty.   What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the doctor who's got Christine Collins locked up in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intercut with:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wheel Christine into the room, struggling, fighting against the straps that pin her to the gurney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steele turns away from Briegleb, unconcerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, we don't discuss our cases with anyone other than family --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll damned well discuss this one with me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briegleb THRUSTS the newspaper into Steele's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read it!   Read it, damn you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steele unfolds the paper, looks at the headline, which we don't see. His reaction, though, is ominous and serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse behind Christine applies the conductor jell to temples. She's fighting the best she can, but it's hopele The nurse picks up the electro-shock pincers. Places them Christine's temples. Reaches for the button --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as suddenly the door opens, and a nurse steps in, stop the process. The nurse goes to the one at the controls, whispers in her ear. The nurse then says something quietl to the orderly, who starts to undo the straps that hold Christine to the gurney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull her up off the gurney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is ushered inside, where Steele is waiting. looks upset about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She forces herself to stand straight, not easy given what she's just been through. He approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One last time. Are you, or are you not, prepared to sign that letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up into his face, her resolve unshaken, her voi dry but firm for:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies her for one last BEAT, then turns his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're free to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine takes a moment to process this...not sure if sh heard this right, or if it's a trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your clothes are in the next room. You can change there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates a second, looks to the orderly, being caref in case this is a set-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. (to the orderly) See to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orderly nods. She takes one last look around, then ge the hell out of the room. Alone, Steele picks up the news that had been laying face-down on his desk, looks at it, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is there as Christine, now in her regular clothes, dashing in. Carol sees her, goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...but I couldn't go without saying goodbye --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine, don't be stupid, get out of here fast in case they change their mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will...but I want you to know: once I have my boy back, I'm coming (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTINE (Cont'd) back here...for you, and the others. This is wrong, and we can stop it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hug. Christine breaks the hug, and hurries away as C looks on, crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine comes to the area where she was checked in. No is looking at her. She passes the nurse's station and hea toward the door. Opens it. Fresh air comes in. Freedom. She steps out the front door as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a moment later, Briegleb passes through the hallway wi an admissions official, having not seen her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give me every piece of paper you've got on this case, you hear me? Every piece!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The official moves on, nervous, as Briegleb looks to the receiving nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When does she come down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before she can answer, we jump out to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Christine walks among the sidewalk traffic. Free. Vindicated. She starts to pass a news-stand, where a NEWS VENDOR is calling out headlines, peddling papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurricane hits West Palm Beach! Babe Ruth hits 53rd home run! Kids found murdered in Riverside!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last line stops Christine...just a bad sense that gro as she turns to the news vendor, who keeps on going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biggest Crime in Los Angeles History! (beat) Collins Boy Assumed Dead on Ranch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine's knees buckle as she hears this. She starts to down as Briegleb runs toward her from the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins...Christine...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...god...no....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she collapses into his arms, sobbing uncontrollably, passers-by glance over at her...and continue walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry...I didn't want you to find out like this...I'm sorry...I'm sorry....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're just words.   She doesn't hear them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Jones is pacing nervously in the hallway for a lo BEAT when another officer steps out of an office with a b nameplate that reads CHIEF OF POLICE JAMES E DAVIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chief will see you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones straightens his tie and steps into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lots of dark wood and filtered light. Davis is sitting at his desk, looking at a series of newspapers in front of h as Jones steps up and stands before the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you're aware of it, Captain, but I have an exceptionally good vocabulary. I'm a terror at Scrabble, crossword puzzles, but even I'm in awe of the vocabulary that the press and the city council have been exercising in reference to this department courtesy of the Christine Collins...incident. (scans papers) Incompetent. Cowardly. Bullying. Reprehensible. Mendacious and invidious...those two courtesy of that prick Gustav Briegleb. Bonus words in Scrabble, both of them. Especially invidious. Hard to work that one into a conversation. But he managed it, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The key, of course, is the context in which words like this get used. You have to do that in scrabble, you know, when somebody challenges a word...show how it's used in a sentence. So "incompetent," as in -- (reads) "A department so incompetent that they never realized that up to twenty children were being kidnapped and murdered under their very noses." (looks over) And here: "So incompetent that they insisted they knew better than a mother the identity of her own child, forced him upon her, and then incarcerated her when she confronted them with evidence of their own reprehensible behavior." That was a two-fer. Incompetent and reprehensible in the same sentence. Guy must be a real terror at crossword puzzles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davis gets up and crosses the room, looking out through t slatted windows at the busy Los Angeles street outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, your handling of the Collins case has exposed this department to public ridicule. There is even the potential for civil and criminal liability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, nobody could have known what was going on up at that ranch. Not us, not the Sheriff's Department, the Marshall's Office...as for the Collins woman.... (beat) I'm still not convinced that her kid is among the victims up in Wineville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JONES (Cont'd) There were four other photos of missing boys that looked a lot like him...this Clark kid could have been mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he was...which raises the obvious question: so what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davis turns back to him from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor wants this to go away. I want this to go away. The way you do that is to stop insisting that Walter Collins was not among those kids killed up at that goddamned ranch. Because if the boy you brought back isn't Walter Collins, and he's not dead up at that ranch, then where the hell is he? People will want to know why we haven't found him. Why we aren't we doing our job. (beat) But if, on the other hand, he is, or could be among those poor boys killed up in Wineville...then the inquiries stop. It's a momentary embarrassment that you'll have to live with...but better a short inconvenience than a lingering problem, wouldn't you say, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones doesn't like it, but he swallows his pride.   Nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy's been gone for nearly a year. If he was going to be found, it would've happened by now. Whether he was up at that ranch or not, the truth is he probably is dead somewhere. Better his mother accepts that now rather than later, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.    That'll be all, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones starts to leave, then looks back as Davis settles b behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, there's talk of an investigation by the police commission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me worry about the commission. But it wouldn't hurt to find out just who the fuck that kid is you brought back from De Kalb and why he did this, because the press bought into his bullshit same as we did. That we were all taken in by the scheming little bastard may help take some of the sting off this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boys are working on it now, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he exits as we go to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Ybarra is sitting on one side of a table, a not in front of him, staring across at "Walter," who isn't ve happy right now, and is staring back with substantial ven His true, nasty personality is free to come out at last. There's a long BEAT, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mocking) "Tough!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Collins is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story
