dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, let me explain something to you. Because of your lies, you've ruined a woman's life embarrassed the police department, and got the whole city up in arms over this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Walter" considers this for a BEAT, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a lot done, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra exchanges a look with the matron, then closes up h notepad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, if that's how you want it, then I guess we're done here. (to matron) Tell County Jail we're remanding him for trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...what's remanding?    What trial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, the real Walter Collins was murdered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? I didn't do anything! I wasn't even here when it happened!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By pretending to be Walter Collins, you're interfering in a police investigation of a kidnapping and murder. We can try you as an accomplice to murder after the fact. (beat) Too bad. County Jail is a lot worse than juvenile hall or a foster home. A lot worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that...I'm just a kid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanford Clark is a kid, too. Fifteen. But he's going to jail. All murderers and their accomplices go to jail. Everyone knows that. (to the matron) Get him out of here. It's out of my hands now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads for the door when "Walter" cries out, scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!   I don't want to go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prove it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on the boy's face, we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur Hutchins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra is standing in the doorway to Jones' office, speak to the Captain and looking at his notepad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy's real name is Arthur Hutchins Junior, age twelve, a runaway from Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you check the wire services?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ybarra holds up a missing persons sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checks out. The report was filed by his divorced mother, who lives in Clinton, Iowa with the boy's grandmother. Apparently he didn't like living with the old lady, she didn't let him get away with the stuff he usually got away with, and one day...he up and left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the man he showed up with at the diner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just some drifter. The boy was hungry, ran into this guy who said he knew how to get some food and not have to pay for it. Only when they finished, he left the kid behind while he cut out. When the police picked him up, they started going through the wire reports about missing kids --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he overheard them say the name Walter Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why that one? I mean, of all the police departments he could've screwed up, why Los Angeles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked him the same question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments earlier.    PUSHING IN on "Walter" for:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I knew that Los Angeles was where they made the Tom Mix movies. I figured maybe I could meet Tom Mix. Maybe he'd even let me ride his horse. (beat) His horse is named Blue. Did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is in a bed in a small room in the rectory, a t beside her, still recovering from her experience. Briegle enters and approaches a nearby chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little better, thanks. The sleep helped. Anything new outside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing that can't wait until you're stronger. The police still have a car parked outside. They want to know what your next move is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a BEAT, then slowly, gingerly gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been giving that a great deal of thought ever since I got out of that...place. All those women, and what they did about Walter.... (beat) They're going to just keep on doing it, aren't they? Nothing's going to change...unless we make it change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances out the window, to the police car parked acro the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to tell Walter, "Never start a fight...but always finish it." I didn't start this fight...but by god I'm going to finish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dangerous, and you've already been through a great deal, Mrs. Collins. Right now you're sufficiently high-profile that the police will hesitate to come after you out in the open...but if they see their position threatened, that could change quickly. (beat) Your life could be in danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a beat, then turns to him from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Always finish it. Always."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of red-brick rowhouses line a quiet street. We s couples walking, hand in hand, kids playing...then we not Gordon Northcott coming around the corner. He looks aroun then cuts across a yard, jumping over a fence to get to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where RACHEL CLARK, 30s, is doing dishes as the doorbell

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door and finds Gordon Northcott standing ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, sis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a flicker of a pause...was she expecting him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon...I didn't know you were back in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got in a couple of days ago, figured I'd surprise you. That okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...yes, of course. Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps aside as he enters, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that little niece of mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She...went into town. Should be back this evening. Bob's here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Need to talk to him about staying on for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staying --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, can I use your bathroom? It's been a long ride and I could use a shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes her and heads upstairs. She steps to the back o the house, where her husband, BOB, is coming in through t back, wiping engine grease off his hands with a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that -- (she nods, scared) Go next door. I'll call the police. Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rushes past him into the other room to do just that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon is toweling off his hair when he hears a car door shut. Then another. He peers out the window. Several Roya Canadian Mounted Police cars have pulled up along the str Mounties are getting out, moving quietly toward the house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob quietly lets the Mounties in. They signal for Bob to the hell out of there. Guns in hand, they climb the stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly there's the SOUND of breaking glass from above. They race up the stairs to find the window broken, and Go fleeing across an adjoining rooftop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go around the other side!    Cut him off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others take off as he and another Mountie climb throu the broken window in pursuit of Northcott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon races up one rooftop, over the top, then leaps to next one as, below, Mounties race to keep up with him, WH blowing furiously. He looks behind him to see the other t Mounties running rooftop to rooftop, coming fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon runs faster, going at angles to put more distance between himself and the police on the ground...and making increasingly more difficult and dangerous leaps from roof to rooftop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaps across one chasm, barely makes it, keeps running The rooftop Mounties follow. One of them makes the jump successfully, but the other falls short, plummeting to th ground three stories below. A leg snaps on impact. The fi Mountie hesitates, looks down. The second one waves him o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on!   Get the bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods and continues the chase. Gordon runs for all he's worth.    The Mountie keeps afte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon makes another leap. The Mountie jumps...but he's s He grabs onto a rain gutter. Gordon sees his situation, r back, and STOMPS on the Mountie's hands, trying to get hi shake loose. The gutter starts to tear free --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- when a Mountie down below FIRES at Gordon, making him off. The Mountie clinging to the gutter starts to fall, t grabs a nearby pipe and crawls up to the roof. Keeps comi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon keeps running...but comes to a chasm too wide to b jumped. He hesitates, starts to cut back in another direc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- when the Mountie TACKLES him hard. The two go down in tangle of limbs, fighting, punching, kicking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They SLIDE down the steeply angled roof and barely avoid over the edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With nowhere else to run, Gordon fights for all he's got, punches from both coming fast and furious. Finally, the Mountie backs off just a bit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw this...I'm too old for this fightin' shit....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and DIVES at Gordon, taking them both off the edge of two-story roof and DOWN into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a garden below, CRASHING through carefully manicured f and trees to land with a THUD, the Mountie's impact cushi by Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the other Mounties come on the run, the first one stag to his feet and yanks up a bruised, bleeding but otherwis intact Gordon. Looks at him nose-to-nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU...ARE UNDER...ARREST!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he YANKS Gordon toward the other waiting officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine opens the door to find Reverend Briegleb and an man on her porch, S. S. HAHN, late fifties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins, I want you to meet a friend of mine, Mr. Hahn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins. My deepest condolences on your loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps aside to let them in, closing the door under:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hahn, was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story                          98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate the sentiment, but so far they still haven't positively identified any of the...remains... as Walter's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he was identified, was he not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but...I guess I still can't accept it. It doesn't feel real to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It never does. I lost a daughter to polio five years ago. There's not a day goes by I don't think, I should mention this to Claudine... then I remember she's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.     Please, sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do as Christine looks to Briegleb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been on the phone all day with the appointment secretary for the police commission. They won't let me testify at the hearing, or call witnesses. They say it's not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. My sources tell me the police commission is going to come out with a report that whitewashes the whole thing. They're going to say that Jones and the rest of the LAPD did absolutely nothing wrong, that the real blame is with the kid...and with you, for being difficult and forcing them to put you away for your own safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll just have to hire a lawyer...bring a civil suit and try to get the City Council to call for a hearing by the Welfare Board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jut one problem. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. BRIEGLEB (Cont'd) Not one lawyer outside this room was willing to take on the Police Department. Too risky, they said. So finally I went to the very best attorney in town, a man who's sued the city four times and won. Unfortunately, we could never afford to hire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crestfallen) I see....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is why I'm doing this pro bono. (a smile) It would be my honor to defend your honor, Mrs. Collins. In my fifteen years as a lawyer, I have never seen anyone fight as long or as hard as you have, in what is so clearly in the cause of justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I want you to tell Mr. Hahn here the whole story, from end to end, leave nothing out, he'll need it all if he's going to get the City Council involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. One thing, though. A personal favor. When we've finished here today, could you spare a few minutes to come with me downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.     Where downtown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hahn marches into the receiving area with Christine Colli and Briegleb. He goes to the receiving nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?   May I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees Christine Collins and the sentence dies midway. Hahn pulls out a handful of papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is S. S. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAHN (Cont'd) Hahn, and I have a court order for the immediate release of all women being detained in this institution under the designation Code Twelve pending a formal inquiry into the reasons for their detainment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but the doctor in charge won't be in until tomorrow morning and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me be clearer. Either you open those doors and produce the people named in that court order, or you will find yourself on the other side of those bars...without a key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse exchanges a sour look with Christine and heads

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One by one, the Code Twelve patients are brought out of t hospital and into the light. One of the last to emerge is Carol Dexter, who blinks against the light, and sees Chri She runs to her, embraces her, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd come...I knew you'd come back...I knew you'd come....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right...everything's going to be all right now....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in Christine's face, we see a flicker of pride and on simple truth: if she could not save her son, she could at least save these women. As they move toward her, Hahn and Briegleb, we HEAR a TRAIN WHISTLE that segues us into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon Northcott, handcuffed, is led out of a train by se officers. The waiting PRESS rush toward him. He seems to enjoy the attention. Among the shouted questions we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Northcott, any comment on your arrest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm feeling fine. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GORDON (Cont'd) I've been on a little vacation, as some of you know. It was a pleasant vacation, and the police have certainly provided me with a lot of amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you avoid capture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't, did I? Didn't know anyone wanted me until just recently. Didn't even try. My luggage still has my initials on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know why the police were after you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I figured it would be best if I stayed out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything to say to the parents of the children you murdered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on that the police hustle Gordon away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davis is filling out paperwork as the door opens. He look up as LOS ANGELES MAYOR GEORGE CRYER enters, closing the after him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayor Cryer...this is unexpected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So was this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops a series of court documents on Davis' desk.   He them up, examines them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subpoenas, requests for depositions, interrogatories...all courtesy of Mr. Hahn and his new client, Christine Collins. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story                            102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRYER (Cont'd) You don't have to look them over too closely, Chief, your own copies should be arriving any time now. (beat) The City Council has also agreed to look into this, starting immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this was supposed to go away. This is an election year, I can't afford this kind of press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is going away, sir.   I instructed Captain Jones --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid falling on his sword and saying he made a mistake isn't going to be good enough, Chief. If we take him out of the picture for a while, it might help calm things down until the hearing's finished. (beat) There are several people on the council who are planning to run against me, and they'd love to accuse me of allowing a renegade police force to operate with impunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cryer shakes his head, walks off a pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our friends in the press are having a field day with this mess. I'm getting five hundred phone calls, letters and telegrams a day demanding to know what the hell is going on at City Hall that we allow our police force to brutalize women and misplace children. Christ, all this picture needs now is for somebody to kick a puppy for the cameras. (beat) This is a train, Chief, and we need to either get in front of it, or be run over by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayor Cryer...I stand by my men. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. And you know where I stand. So the question is..are we going to stand together...or hang together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets the question sit as we go to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayor Cryer stands beside Chief Davis and addresses a rat noisy and worked-up press corps from behind a podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen...gentlemen, please. As Mayor of Los Angeles, it is my duty to preserve the peace in our city, which has been disrupted by recent events in the case of Christine Collins. As a result, we have decided that Captain J. J. Jones of the Lincoln Heights Division is to be suspended from active duty, effective immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the charge, Chief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The charge is conduct unbecoming an officer, and using improper and abusive language toward Mrs. Collins. It further charges that he exceeded his authority as a police officer by incarcerating Mrs. Collins on the alleged charge of insanity without sufficient cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayor Cryer, are you aware that the City Council has said it plans to open its own investigation into the Collins case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard this, yes. But since one of the main purposes of such a hearing by the City Council would be to suspend Captain Jones, and since that action has now been taken, the question is moot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which makes it look like the only reason Jones is being suspended is to head off the City Council (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REPORTER (Cont'd) investigation. Are you concerned that an outside investigation might go uncomfortably high up the food chain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't even dignify that question with a response. Good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two head back into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glancing back over their shoulders at the press outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheer up, Chief. That little show should take the wind out of their sails. By Monday, this issue will be as cold as yesterday's fish. Never underestimate the public's lack of attention and potential for apathy. Old news is dead news, you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door as Briegleb enters with three really l dangerous looking men, one of whom is carrying a heavy tr coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend, what --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to barge in so late, Mrs. Collins, but it took me a while to find the right people for the right job. These three gentlemen are members of my congregation who, before coming to the Lord, had lived lives of brutality, vice and crime. Now they are pledged to doing god's work...and if this isn't it, I don't know what is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People who bring charges against the police have a habit of (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIEGLEB (Cont'd) disappearing right before the trial. I'm a big believer in the power of prayer, Mrs. Collins...but a little backup from time to time never hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others nod as they make themselves comfortable in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see...well, I...thank you.   Can I get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since we don't plan on sleeping, coffee would be lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads off to get some coffee. As one of the men puts coat behind the sofa, we see that it contains a sawed-off shotgun. Briegleb looks out the window, to where a police car sits, watching the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's dressed in her best dress, putting on a hat and a p of gloves. Her hands are shaking. She squeezes them toget closes her eyes. Focuses. With one final, deep breath, sh heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same police car is there as Christine gets into a car with Briegleb and the two drive off. The other three men into another car and follow. The police car in turn pulls away from the curb, following both cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's aware that they're being followed, glancing in the r view mirror to keep an eye on things. Looks over to Chris smiles encouragingly. Looks ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traffic's getting heavy.   We'll go up Spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns. The other cars do the same. But the traffic her is even worse. Just then, Briegleb looks back in his rear view mirror to see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- another police car pulling out of a driveway and cutti off the car with Christine's bodyguards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briegleb turns quickly, trying to get ahead, but the stre too busy. He looks in the mirror to see that another poli car glide into position two cars behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traffic stops. Jammed. Briegleb is nervous, sensing the very real possibility of a hit being set up. The traffic lined right up against parked cars on either side. Then there's a momentary break in traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns hard into the driveway of a closed shop and shut off the engine. Jumps out and opens the door for Christin who gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start walking. Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do. He glances back at the police car. The two insid start to open the doors, but they can't get them open, be right up against parked cars on one side and traffic on t other. They run the siren to clear traffic, but it's too late as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Christine and Briegleb hurry down the street on foot, Briegleb glancing behind them. The foot- and car-traffic very heavy...we HEAR horns honking and, in the distance, something that could be the sound of lots of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost there. Just a few more blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is all this traffic's coming from...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briegleb glances back. The police car has popped its door and two trench-coated officers are getting out. Christine stops a man passing in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, can you tell me what the problem is up ahead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear? It's the biggest protest I've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Protest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...over that Collins broad, if you can believe that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves on. Briegleb and Collins slowly exchange a look somewhere between disbelief and "oh shit."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't mean...he couldn't mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...all I know is that I think I just stopped breathing....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk quickly up one clogged street and down another, police following on foot...moving toward the SOUND of voi drums, and cars honking... until they turn onto Spring St

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and find themselves in the middle of the biggest prote march ever recorded in the history of Los Angeles to this date. Thousands of people crowd into the street, overwhel the police presence...not rioting, but making their voice heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Salvation Army, the Women's Temperance Society, the S for Justice, Catholic groups, Union groups and ordinary citizens carrying placards and signs that read WE SUPPORT CHRISTINE COLLINS and JUSTICE FOR MRS. COLLINS and THE LA A CITY'S SHAME...it just goes on and on and on. Christine looks out to see her boss from the telephone company, Mr. Harris, marching arm in arm with the rest. He sees her, smiles, tips his hat and continues marching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is stunned...Briegleb even moreso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord works in mysterious ways, Mrs. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks behind them, to where the police have stopped. There's no way in hell they can make a move in the face o something as big as t his. Briegleb smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy howdy, does He ever.   Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue up the street toward City Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen...can I have your attention, please....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a big room, and one thousand observers fill every available chair with more standing along the wall in back It's a circus. Christine sits with Hahn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briegleb is in a seat behind the main section.    FLASHBU pop as THORPE, a city councilman, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are nearly one thousand people gathered in this chamber, more than have ever been in this room before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speakers are lowered from the window into the parking lot where hundreds of others are gathered to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on pa) I therefore ask you to refrain from demonstrations of any kind. We're all here because we want to find out the real facts in this case, and everybody is going to be heard if we have to sit here for a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Thorpe looks to the other members of the Council, and area where witnesses are supposed to wait to be called up A number of seats are empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Thorpe, I don't see any other members of the Police Commission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's odd...we specifically stipulated that we would begin our hearings with testimony from the police department. Are there any representatives of the Police Commission in the room? (no answer) Is Chief Davis here? (no reply) Is Captain Jones here? Is there anyone here representing the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REPORTER raises his hand, then stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman...Richard Thomas, The Evening Herald. Both the Police Chief and Captain Jones are in San Pedro for a police inspection at a station there. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REPORTER (Cont'd) Only reason I know is we have a couple of our boys out covering the thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you telling me they directly violated the wishes of the City Council? That they refused to attend a vital hearing so they could conduct a routine inspection in San Pedro? And what the hell is Jones doing at an inspection after being suspended? (beat) I hate to call a recess before we've even started, but I think a few phone calls are in order. So we'll take a half hour break, then continue with the witnesses who have appeared here today. But let it be known that Captain Jones and Police Chief Davis will be subpoenaed and required to appear here tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's APPLAUSE from the crowd which breaks up into pock of discussion as a BAILIFF approaches Hahn and whispers i his ear. Hahn nods, looks to Christine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins, could you come across the street with me for just a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...shouldn't we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think there's something you should see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puzzled, curious, Christine gets up and exits with Hahn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hahn is moving quickly down the hall toward a courtroom d Christine following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the police decided it was best to keep this off the main docket in order to avoid exactly the sort of chaos we have across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets to the door, pauses. Looks back to her.    She no He opens the door and they enter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead silence, in marked contrast to the city council room As she enters, she sees people sitting silently in the gallery...row after row of couples, mothers and fathers, weeping softly. Some of them notice Christine's entrance nod to her with sadness and a strange sense of common bond...they are all carrying the same grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the couples, MR. AND MRS. CLAY, see Christine and to her, speaking softly. They should be distinct enough i appearance that we will recognize them instantly when we them again later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins? I'm Leanne Clay, this is my husband, John...I just wanted to pass on my sympathies. What we went through, waiting to hear anything about our son David, was bad enough, and now this.... (beat) But there was no call for what the police did to you...no call at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods her thanks as a door at the other end of the cou opens. They take their seats as a judge and two attorneys take their places, preceded by a bailiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do. The judge takes his seat. The rest of the room also sits. He nods to the bailiff, who in turn opens anot door, leading to the holding area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Christine looks on, Gordon Stewart Northcott is ushere into the courtroom for his initial plea. Some women break into tears at the sight of him. He first seems startled b the presence of so many, then he smiles. An audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he takes his place beside his attorney, he looks down room and meets the gaze of Christine Collins. Her face pa as though slapped...but she doesn't look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey...I saw you in the papers. You got a lot of moxie, standing up to the police like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bailiff forcibly turns him around to face the judge. Christine's hands grip the seat she's in until her knuckl turn white...but she doesn't allow him the satisfaction o seeing her react to his comments. The judge looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon Stewart Northcott, you have been charged with three counts of murder in the first degree, with an additional seventeen counts under review by the district attorney's office. How do you plea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not guilty, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances back at his audience.   The bailiff rights him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In light of the defendant's penchant for international travel, no bail will be set. This court will receive preliminary motions by tomorrow morning, with a trial date to be set for the earliest opening on the court's calendar. (beat) The defendant is remanded into custody. Bailiff....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bailiff removes Gordon, who shares one last look with audience, and Christine in particular. He winks at her. S doesn't give him a flicker of satisfaction with a reactio But once he's gone, she sits heavily and covers her eyes, fighting tears. Hahn puts a hand on her shoulder, but say nothing. There's nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy, Walter Collins, was reported as missing on March 10, 1928.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones is at last on the stand. Hahn stands before him, th rest of the City Council, Christine and the huge audience looking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We then instituted a nationwide search. On July 10, we received a cable indicating that a boy matching his description had been found in De Kalb, Illinois. Upon questioning, he admitted to being Walter Collins, and we made arrangements to transport him back to California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Mrs. Collins told you the boy was not her son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She denied his identity in spite of all evidence pointing to the contrary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as subsequent events have demonstrated, she was correct. So what prompted you to send her for psychological evaluation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether or not this was in fact the correct boy was not relevant to my decision. Throughout this period, she acted strangely. She was often cool, aloof and unemotional, especially when presented with the boy we located in De Kalb, and in our subsequent conversations. It was because of her disturbing behavior that I submitted her for observation to the psychopathic ward of Los Angeles County General Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that. You snap your fingers and an innocent woman is thrown into the psycho ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hahn turns away, playing to the council and the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every home in this state is in grave danger when a Police Captain can take a woman into his office and, five minutes later, have her thrown into the psychopathic ward on his own authority!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd applauds and cheers.    Joes fights to be heard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the crowd) She wasn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't thrown.     She was... escorted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's laughter from the gallery.   He doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escorted, thrown, the verb doesn't matter, Captain. What does matter is that her incarceration was ordered without a warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hahn goes to the exhibit table, picks up several papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am holding a carbon copy of the affidavit of insanity that was issued in the case of the State of California vs. Christine Collins. Who signed the affidavit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is the date on this document?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September 12th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mrs. Collins was incarcerated on September 6th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The form is backdated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, so it would appear. The bottom of the page is reserved for recording where and when the warrant was served. But it has not been filled in. May I assume from this that the warrant was never served?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's correct. There was no need to serve the warrant since she was at that time already in custody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see if I have this straight. A woman was thrown into the psychopathic ward without a warrant, because no warrant existed, and when it was finally written six days later, there was no need to sign it or go to a judge because (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAHN (Cont'd) she was already in the asylum!      Is this correct, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technically...yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More murmuring from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extraordinary steps were necessary because we were dealing with an extraordinary situation! Is it our fault that we were being deceived by the boy who claimed to be Walter Collins? No. In light of his claims and her behavior, who wouldn't begin to wonder if there was something wrong with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she questioned you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she wouldn't listen, because she insisted on being obstinate and taking matters into her own hands best left to qualified officers, because --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she was fighting for the life of her son! A boy who may have still been alive while you were wasting valuable time denying you had done anything wrong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This silences both Jones and the crowd. You could hear a drop. Hahn approaches Jones, and now speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in the end, that's what happened, isn't it? At some point, while all this was going on, Walter Collins died along with as many as nineteen other youths on the Northcott Ranch in Wineville. Is that correct, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones looks to Chief Davis.   It's a moment.    Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine's face falls into her hands.   The place erupts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No further questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hahn walks away from a devastated looking Jones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small crowd is assembled at the front of the station, w Chief Davis stands with the Boy who had been "Walter" as train pulls up before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- so after much effort, we were able to identify this boy, who was has been responsible for so much recent trouble, as Arthur Hutchins of Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Between this, and the arrest of the man suspected of murdering the real Walter Collins, we have cleared up two of the biggest mysteries in the history of Los Angeles. (beat) I hope that you gentlemen of the press will give as much space to the good things we do as the mistakes that are made on rare occasions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, he turns as a Matron comes off the train with HUTCHINS, middle thirties, the boy's mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, let me introduce you to the boy's real mother, Mrs. Janet Hutchins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to him and hugs him. "Walter" looks like he wish he were somewhere on Mars. Davis moves closer to them to in frame while the FLASHBULBS pop. She's in the same pose they got Christine to take when she "accepted" her lost s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope he hasn't been too much trouble for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, not at all....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He towsels the boy's head like he'd like to cut it off. T he nods to an aide, who approaches with a bundle of cloth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hutchins...Mrs. Collins, the woman he was staying with, wanted him to have these. They're the clothes she let him wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you. Isn't that nice, Arthur? Tell the nice officer thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want 'em! Give 'em to somebody else!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precocious little fellow, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my fault! It was the police! They said I was Walter Collins, not me! It wasn't my idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She yanks him away.   Davis smiles gamely at the reporter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There...blame the police for your own mistakes. We've seen a lot of that lately, haven't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot MOS, under MUSIC, somber and moving, INTERCUTTING be the two trials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine on the stand, speaking quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Ybarra on the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief Davis on the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murder jury being shown photographs of the Northcott Walter's dentist showing a drawing of Walter's teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His teacher, Mrs. Fox, also testifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bits of clothing entered into evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Steele testifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ending on Christine seated, reserved, holding it all in.. watching. We HOLD on her face to bring us into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is sitting on Walter's bed. She runs a hand alo the sheets, straightening and smoothing them out, her eye moist but not crying. We HEAR a knock on the front door downstairs, and the door opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm up here, Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues as Briegleb comes up the stairs and enters room. Sees her. Takes off his hat. A show of sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Walter was...when he was here, I'd walk past his bedroom when he was asleep, and even if I couldn't see him, or hear him, I could...feel him in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mothers and their children are connected in amazing ways. My uncle joined the army during the big war, and the day he died, before we ever heard a word about it, my grandmother woke up in the middle of the night and said, "Bobby's gone." She just...knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine nods, taking it in, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I don't think Walter is dead. I can still feel him, in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what the police said. But the remains...what they found on that ranch is so...most of it can't even be properly identified. What if that boy made a mistake when he picked Walter's picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand that you don't want to accept this. What mother does? But you have to let go...and start over. For yourself. He'd want you to move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. And maybe he'd want me to keep looking. Maybe he's waiting for me, somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is, Christine. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. BRIEGLEB (Cont'd) In that place where we will all be reunited with our loved ones someday. And on that day, he will know, front to back, end to end, heart and soul... that you did everything you could, Christine. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods absently, finishes adjusting the sheets.   He ch his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods again, and stands. He heads out of the room, and she lingers for a moment, taking one last look around bef turning off the night-light, and sees the drawing he made the two of them walking together beneath an orange sun. H on that image as we HEAR a gavel hammering and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This meeting will now come to order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSHING IN on Thorpe, at the center of the council's long table, addressing the crowd and Christine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Committee has now heard all of the testimony, and in light of the facts presented, issues the following statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Northcott stands before the judge, jury, and the gr family members.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Foreman, has the jury reached a verdict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still pushing in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the City Council has no power to directly remove commissioners or (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THORPE (Cont'd) the employees who serve under them, it nevertheless can perform the function of making recommendations. This committee therefore reports and recommends: (beat) First, that the majority members of the Police Commission deserve the severest condemnation for their decision to whitewash the Collins case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APPLAUSE erupts from the gallery at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quietly PUSHING IN on Northcott, the Judge, Jury, others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailiff, will you bring me the verdict of the jury?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bailiff complies. The judge reads it, hands it back t the Bailiff, who brings it back to the Foreman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second, we recommend that the suspension of Captain Jones be made permanent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even louder applause, some cheering. The pattern continue through the balance of the statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Northcott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will the defendant please rise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Northcott rises, still smiling, defiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third, that steps be taken to investigate a change in the prevailing laws and procedures by (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story                                 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THORPE (Cont'd) which a citizen of this city can be subjected to incarceration in the county's mental facilities. (beat) Finally, restoration of public confidence in the police department can only be achieved by the removal of its chief of police, and this committee so recommends. (beat) This hearing is concluded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place explodes with cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the foreman stands again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may read the verdict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We the jury find the defendant, Gordon Stewart Northcott...guilty on all counts of murder in the first degree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are gasps and cries and tears...but Northcott is de

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the defendant wish to make a statement before judgment is passed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I want to make a statement. I want to make it real clear that I never once got a fair shake from you, your "honor," or this court. The only one of you here worth a goddamn is her -- (points to christine) -- 'cause she's the only one never badmouthed me to the press. She understands what it is when the police frame you for something you didn't do and throw you in the hole. Isn't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks to her.   She doesn't flinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to know, Mrs. Collins, I never killed your boy. I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough! Counsel, you will get control of your client or I will have him bound and gagged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The defense attorney yanks Gordon around to face the judg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon Stewart Northcott, it is the judgment of this court that you will be conveyed to San Quentin Prison, where you will be held in solitary confinement for a period of two years, until October 2nd, 1930. On that date, you are to be hanged by the neck until dead. May god have mercy on your soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he brings down the gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is standing outside, putting the horrors of the out of her thoughts, as a door opens and Chief Davis come out, followed by several reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- no, as I said after the hearing, I have every intention of finishing my term as Chief of the Los Angeles Police Department. I will not resign. I will fight to the finish. The Collins case was merely an excuse for certain politicians who have been trying to have me removed for some time, and I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses as he sees Christine.    Looks away and continu a lowered voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- anyway, I remain confident that the Mayor's office will stand firmly behind me. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press continue after him, not really noticing Christi who takes one last look around at it all...and walks slow away. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine, alone, rides the street car to work. The car s in front of a school. Walter's school. She looks out the window, to where children are playing. Then looks away ag as the street-car starts moving again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is back at work again, as she had been, though of the light has gone out of her eyes. She moves from sta to station, nodding her approval or checking off forms. S glances to the clock, it's a little after two, then goes Mr. Harris, who has just come out onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten minute break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts away, turning at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know...one of these days you might consider actually taking one of these ten minute breaks. Might be good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see.     Thanks, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads off toward a back room. He watches her go with combination of awe, respect and deep sadness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is on the telephone, crossing off contact numbe on a pad of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, hello, this is Christine Collins, we spoke yesterday about my son...fine, thank you. I was wondering if you'd had a chance to go through the file on runaways in your area in case anyone resembling Walter had -- (beat) I see. No, thank you, I appreciate the information. Would it be all right if I called you again, in a month or so? Thank you. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She checks his number off her list as Hahn appears in the partially open door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's heard part of the conversation, and there's a sadnes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to dial again when he knocks on the door. turns to see him, mid-dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, I was just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. That's...why I wanted to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His tone is grave, and she knows that something's happene She hangs up the phone, missing the cradle the first time

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about Walter. We had...well, we received a very strange telegram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon Northcott.   He's...he's asked to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he knows you're still looking for your son, and before he dies -- (beat) He says that he lied when he testified that he didn't kill Walter. He's willing to finally admit that he did it. He says that if you come up to see him, in person...he'll tell you the truth, to your face...so that you can get on with your life and have some peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is on the train headed north.   The telegram is her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you know, he's set to be executed the day after tomorrow at San Quentin, so.... (beat) You don't have a lot of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets out of a taxi in front of the prison.    It's a grim sight, and moves toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Took me most of the morning to make all the arrangements. Turns out you're the first woman in thirty years the state has allowed to visit a serial killer on the night of his execution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four bare walls and a long table. Two chairs. One window, behind bars and chicken wire. Christine waits, alone. The we HEAR footsteps approaching down the hall. A moment lat a PRISON GUARD escorts Northcott into the room. Northcott nods to Christine, then glances to the guard, who looks t Christine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can stay in the room if you want, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm...sure I'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right...I'll be right outside the door if you need anything. (to northcott) Twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard exits, leaving the two alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't suppose you've got a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, walks to the window to a nearby structure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where they do it, you know. That building right over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where they do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hangings. Ten o'clock tonight, I get to see what's inside. I hear there's thirteen steps going up to the gallows...'cause thirteen is unlucky. Helps make sure you're gonna go to hell when you die. But I got 'em beat. I outsmarted 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks to Christine, smiles nervously, glances back out window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gonna let me have whatever I want for dinner. Got a steak coming, with spinach, mashed potatoes and green beans. I always wondered why they did that whole last meal thing. One of the other guys on Death Row said when you take the drop, you foul yourself, and everything you ate...comes out the other end. So maybe that's why they make sure you got something in you when it happens. They like knowing you fouled yourself on the way to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops himself.   Turns from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you don't got a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head.   He nods absently for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warden, Clinton Duffy, he's a good guy. He's writing a book about all the death sentences he's carried out in this place. Says it's called "Eighty-Eight Men and Two Women." Beats my record all to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Northcott...you asked me to come to see you. You said if I did, you would tell me the truth about my son. Well, I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...yeah, you are. But see, the thing is, I didn't think you'd really come, and now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's pacing, growing more agitated and scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't expect.... (beat) I don't want to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do this...I can't talk to you...not today, not tonight, not with what they're going to do to me. It's one thing to send a telegram, that's easy, but right now, right here, in person, I -- (beat) I can't tell you what you want to hear, Mrs. Collins. I can't, I can't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't want to die with a lie on my lips!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns from her, in anguish...but is he just playing he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did my penance, I asked God to forgive me for my sins...and I've been good, ever since...if I commit a sin now, if I lie now...I'm out of time, I can't be forgiven again... I don't want to go to hell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes around to him, faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Northcott...look at me. (beat) Look at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns almost against his will...meets her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you...kill...my son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes go wide and he CRIES OUT, stumbling back and awa from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from me...I don't know anything about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Northcott --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm innocent! (pounds door) Guard! Guard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard enters, going to Northcott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, wait, please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, ma'am, they always get a little nuts the day of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes past him to Northcott, grabs the front of his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you kill him? Did you kill my son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He screams in anguish, and the guard hauls him out, closi the door after him. Christine tries to open the door, but won't open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Northcott...Mr. Northcott!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slowly slides to the floor, crying as we HEAR the SOU of CHAINS clanking, and we....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the prison yard opens and closes as Northcott led into the area with the scaffolding. The Warden is the waiting at the foot of the gallows, along with a chaplain

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several other parents, including Mr. and Mrs. Clay, are i the witness gallery at the back, separated from the gallo area by a large plate glass window. Christine is among th parents. The Clays see her, and put a hand on her arm for strength. Christine nods, accepting it, and moves to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Northcott, legs and arms bound in chains, makes his way t the warden at the base of the gallows. A clock reads 9:50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon Stewart Northcott, you have been found guilty of murder, the penalty for which is death by hanging. There have been no stays or reprieves, therefore the execution will go forward as stipulated under the laws of the State of California. Do you have any last words?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...nothing. (to chaplain) I kept clean after I confessed, reverend...just like I said I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chaplain nods silently as the warden looks to the gua who begin to escort Northcott up the steps to the gallows

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will it...will it hurt? (no reply) Please...not so fast...don't make me walk so fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They struggle with him now, pushing and carrying him up t last of the thirteen steps to the top. They tie his legs together, and cinch his arms tightly in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirteen steps...thirteen steps... but I didn't touch all of 'em, you bastards...I didn't touch all of 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to slip a black felt mask over his head and se the rope. He looks desperately to the witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prayer! Please, somebody, say a prayer for me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mask goes on and is tightened into place. The executi approaches the handle that will open the trap door. The w looks to the clock...9:59. From beneath the hood we HEAR, a terrified, shaking voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent night...holy night...all is calm...all is bright...round yon virgin mother and child...holy infant so tender and mild --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then the warden nods to the executioner who pulls th lever and the trap door JERKS OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Northcott FALLS through the door six feet then there's a SNAP...and the body bounces in SLOW MOTION at the end of rope...as we HEAR the sound of his heart slowing...slowing...until it finally stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine covers her eyes. There is no cheering in the wi room. Only the sound of weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, the witnesses exit the prison. We find Christine among them. She nods good-night to some of them, includin the Clays, then starts off on her own, heading into the n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And: SEVEN YEARS AFTER THE DISAPPEARANCE OF WALTER COLLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to ESTABLISH, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brass plate on the partially open door announces C. COLLINS, ASSISTANT MANAGER. She's filling out paperwork a there's a KNOCK and a group of other employees and operat appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Chris...we're having an Oscar party tonight at my apartment, you want to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't...I've got a million forms to fill out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, please, they can wait --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy, you guys blew out the phone lines between here and Baltimore, someone has to clean up the mess, and that's me. Besides, I've got a radio right here, I can follow the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Positive.    Go on, have fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head off. Christine focuses on her work.     There's knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I can't go --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up to see Ben Harris in the doorway.    He smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm meeting some friends for dinner at Musso and Frank's on Hollywood. They're going to pipe the Oscar ceremony through to the restaurant. Should be quite a night. I'd love it if you'd come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, that's very sweet, and I wish I could...but I really need to stay and finish this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, taking the rejection well.   Starts off when:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben...? I put down two dollars on "It Happened One Night" for best picture. Seems I'm the only one here who thinks it has a chance against "Cleopatra." If I win, how about we have dinner tomorrow night to celebrate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a deal, Christine.   Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about I call you if you win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with a smile, he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night shift operators are working, a smaller group bu still busy. We PAN through them until we start to HEAR th sound of radio-miked applause, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on radio) Thank you. And now, it gives me distinct honor to present the category of Best Picture for 1934.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Christine is still working as the Academy Awards of 1935 play themselves out on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on radio) The nominees are "The Gay Divorcee," "Here Comes the Navy," "The Barrets of Wimpole Street," "One Night of Love," "The Thin Man," "Cleopatra" --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over-rated....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on radio) "Viva Villa," "The White Parade," and "It Happened One Night."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark Gable, Claudette Colbert.   I rest my case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on radio) And the Oscar for Best Picture goes to.... (beat) "It Happened One Night."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APPLAUSE comes through the radio...and Christine is as pl as if she'd just won herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out door) I knew it...I knew it!   I told you so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just about to go back to her work when the phone ri She picks it up, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, it looks like dinner is on me, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops.   It's not Ben on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, this is she. Mrs. Clay? No, of course I remember you, how are you? Is everything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She freezes at something she hears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? Where did they -- (beat) No, of course...I'll be right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, grabs her coat, and races out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine climbs out of a taxi and rushes into the statio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine is ushered into a room with a long two-way mirr that looks out into an interview room. Mr. and Mrs. Clay already there. In the other room is Detective Ybarra, and young boy, DAVID, age 13. Mrs. Clay sees her, and they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to go to him right off, but they said it was important to talk to him alone first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they sure it's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're sure, but more important, I'm sure. (beat) It's my boy, all right...it's David. He's alive, Christine. They found him up in Hysperia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clay motions for them to shush. They turn their atten to the other room, where Ybarra looks up from making note

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, so after you got into the car, what happened next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drove me around for a long time, then we ended up at this ranch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is shoved into the chicken coop. Several other BOYS are already there, scared, crying. They lunge at the door trying to get out, but it slams shut in their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They scream, trying to get out.   Gordon SLAMS an arm aga the door, scaring them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHUT UP! (grinning) I'll see you boys later....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs and moves off, Sanford accompanying him, lookin very guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were there other boys present?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...six, I think. It was a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you speak to them? Do you remember any of their names?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING the boys huddled against one wall, scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...two of them were brothers, I think their last name was Winslow, something like that. The oldest was Jeffrey, I think he was around eleven.... (beat) ...and Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We STOP PAN on the last kid...on Walter Collins, at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Christine REACTS to this, her hand flying to her mouth Not daring to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember his last name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christine covers her face.     Can barely stand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if you only remember some of the names of the rest, how come you remember his full name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of the kids, Walter and Jeffrey, are sitting in a cor talking quietly, urgently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Jeffrey were talking when everybody else was screaming. They were scared, same as the rest of us, but they weren't scared stupid. They kept checking around until they found a part of the coop where the chicken wire was all messed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull at the wiring.    Part of the roof weakens and sifts down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They figured we might be able to yank the chicken wire and bring down the corner, maybe make enough room to get out of there and run... but it would make an awful lot of noise and if it wasn't wide enough, we'd be stuck. It might even bring the whole place down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta try it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!   What he hears --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in an echo of what he told his mother the last time h saw her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. I'm not afraid of anything. (beat) Don't you want to go home? Don't you want to see your mom again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Winslow kids nod, and start crying.   Jeffrey and Wal look to the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David holds up his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Anybody who doesn't want to come, get over at that end in case this comes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Winslow boys and two others scramble to the other end too terrified to try and escape. Jeffrey, David and Walte go to the weakened corner of the coop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we get out, we split up, go in different directions, they can't catch all of us. Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nod, and get into position, each taking a part of th wire framework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do so, pulling for all they're worth...struggling... ceiling SHIFTS above them, dirt falling all over the plac they pull harder, the wire cutting into fingers, but stil pulling...then suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the corner FALLS AWAY, part of the roof starting to co down with it. The NOISE is substantial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANGELING A True Story

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They race out the opening, Jeffrey first, then Walter, th David...but just as the first two get clear --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter turns to see David stuck in the wiring. LIGHTS go around the ranch. He hesitates...then RUNS back to David, helps to untangle him. They HEAR a SHOTGUN blast, and FEE running their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
